content:
Posted: January 5
												This is one of those games that is special. It isn't perfect, nor is it amazing, but it's definitely special. The concept is simple, your typical Diablo clone (though it feels more like Gauntlet) with a bit of Little Big Planet. There isn't a whole lot of Little Big Planet influenced content. For example, the way you can customize your character is limited. You find loot and you wear it. The loot makes your character both look different as well boosts some stats, enable some abilities, etc. Little Big Planet wins hard by character customization. As far as level creation goes, it wins as far as I can tell. Maybe it doesn't win by content, for Little Big Planet wins hands down as far as content you can mess with, but this game wins as far as control to the point you can actually make some pretty fun quests.The gameplay is simplistic. You attack, you level up, you develop a play style, you get better, you attack more. You finish levels for loot, coins, and xp. Loot and coins can both be donated to a "shrine" in your home level (or pod, if you're thinking little big planet, but you cannot customize it like you could your pod in LBP). When you donate enough and then pray, you then unlock randomly options you can choose from such as a better item, stamina boost, health boost, inventory increase, etc. There is one thing unique beyond all of this, you're doing all of this for one major objective. You are leveling yourself up and grinding for better items so you can fight a dragon. Shocker, a game called Fight the Dragon and it's all about fighting a dragon. The catch is that it has a lot of health, 1 million HP to be exact, and your goal is to fight it and deal as much damage as possible. If you die, the hp doesn'treset. You can die and come back later, continuing where you have left off. This is a cool, interesting, unique game feature. Considering how low of a price this game is, the fact it still has a four pack, and how enjoyable it is, I'd say it's worth full price easily. If you want, you can easily wait for a sale where it goes nearly half off, which is an even more incredible deal. The game might not get 100 hours from me, but I'll get my money's worth.

number of helpful: 6 of 8 people (75%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 18, 2016
												Note: As it stands, I can't really recommend it. I might play more later and this could change, but it is as it stands.Fight the dragon is your base RPG formula. Pick a class, fight monsters, get gear, level up; and eventually hit the key component: Fight the Dragon. I won't go about telling you what classes there are, cause like all RPG's there is the main variety. You got your physical, your magical, and your dexterity.What I want to get into the grit about is the gameplay. Playing the game feels a bit stiff or awkward in most cases, and it's mostly attributed to hitboxes. When you attack someone there's a good chance you'll hit them if you're so close to them you're clipping inside, but other than that you can seriously end up missing for stupid reaesons that can result in you dying very quickly.Even when fighting skeletons in the tutorial, I found several times that I'd take swings at them and watch my blade go through them with no damage done, but they do the same in return and actually manage to connect to me. There's also been times where I'd attack and it'd hit, starting off a combo. But wait! The enemy was nudged back a bit, so I miss the rest of my combo by a hair, letting me take more damage.The real struggle is with elevated platforms and ranged enemies. Did you know I honestly thought wraiths couldn't be hurt by basic attacks at first? Cause I'd get within breathing range and swing and they'd fly right through me without it connecting, but only after a few more attempts did I Realize they can in fact be hit. This was mostly because most of the time they were hovering above me just enough to have it not count.Which brings me to elevation. A platform that's short enough to the point where you can walk up onto it without a climb should not prevent me from attacking an enemy that my sword is going right through their ankles! And when you are on a map with ranged way above where the player cant reach? You can ♥♥♥♥ right off. Especially with custom maps that like using these types of enemies.That said, all the maps in the game are - aside from the provded - custom. This is the main key, and this naturally leads to some really unbalanced situations with custom maps, but dev maps are pretty reasonable for the most part.Suggestions- Make hitboxes a bit more reasonable. You can size it out even half an inch or more and it'd be an improvement- Lower health on ranged enemies. It's bad enough they sprint away from you at twice your speed- FIX BLOCKING. Seriously, that thing is bipolar. Even at maximum health, it struggles to do jack♥♥♥♥♥♥half the time. Sometimes it feels like you need to block, and sometimes it feels like that axe needs to go past it into your face.

number of helpful: 13 of 22 people (59%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 15, 2014
Early Access Review
								Not played long, I play in short spurts, but what I've played I've enjoyed, the graphics are fun if functional, the loot is interesting, the developers do regular updates, which other devs should take note of, and the game is overall a lot of fun. It's simple but there's a lot of variety in the gameplay, it all ends up being hack slash loot, but they try to mix it up with puzzles, and mix the original maps with user generated maps. I really enjoyed this title, especially at the price point it is. The loot system is fun, and allows you to customise almost all aspects of armour, which all offer different varying attributes for your character.It can be too simple at times, but I think this is meant to be the little big planet of hack slash loot titles. It has nostalgic feelings of gauntlet, and dungeon crawlers. The graphics variety is nice, sound effects are adequate, but its he gameplay and the loot that keeps me coming back for more.Oh and that dragon, what a B*, fun as hell, but difficult too. There's plenty of updates that add more and more items, more loot, more enemies and so on. The fact that it has a very simple interface means that creating custom user generated levels with the tools at hand is not a difficult feat.All in all I really really like where this game is headed, and would definitely recommend it amongst the recent crop of Early Access titles

content:
Posted: March 30, 2016
												This game is freaking fantastic! I bought it almost as after after-though since I do like Diablo, but I'm not a huge fan of Little Big Planet... So the description threw me off at first. If you have any doubts about the game, check out some videos on You Tube, they'll give you a pretty good idea about the gameplay. It's a great game and lots of fun... :)One other thing that threw me off: There is no selling of loot in this game. I thought, "What good is a game with loot if you can't sell it to buy better gear?!?" But all is well... This game has a very unique system whereas you "donate" your gold that you pick up as well as items you decide not to keep. Yeah, that sounds like fun, right? But what you get in return is awesome... The gold and each item has a value and as you donate more, you increase in level as to how good of an item (or special skill or whatever) that you get in return when you "pray" (in other words, choose to cash in on your generosity). It works very well in this game and is easy to get used to. Very inventive!I haven't built any levels myself yet... Just been having fun playing levels that other folks have built... And I've already come across some great ones! Very, very cool, and lots of fun! Been playing with an X-Box 360 controller and it works great. It's definitely a pick up and play game, but I can see I'm going to get hours sucked out of my life with this one. Definite Two Thumbs Up!

content:
Posted: May 23, 2014
Early Access Review
								After playing this game for some hours I find it quite enjoying. Though there are still some few bugs, it plays great, sometimes it doesn't feel like an early acces game at all! I use the feature to just click a tile and it chooses a next adventure for me. This way you never know what you are going to get and it can be a surprise in a good or bad way! One of the very fun parts of this game is that as a user you can create your own adventures, so there are some great user created maps out there! Also some less fun, but you can delete those and play the other ones. You also get a notification in case the world map gets an update, and you can play the map again. After completing the map, you can rate it to the user and tell him what you thought about the map. Like a normal adventure game, you run around killing mobs for loot and money. There are different types of loot as in other games, and you can equip your character with with loot designed for his class. Even though it is in early acces, I find this game lots of fun, and there are regular updates in which they implement new items and features!

content:
Posted: February 22, 2015
												Probably one of the most charming and innovative little games i have ever come across. Fight the Dragon allows it's players to develop an RPG style character while at the same time, building their own worlds/levels and even allowing you to share your own and play other people's levels. The artwork style is very very attractive and the game runs great. It will take anyone a little while to grasp some of the mechanics of the level builder but within the hour you'll be cruising along setting traps, spawning trolls and building towering castle walls. The building style is essentially Minecraft but with a blank canvas and on a much grander scale. Sadly however the community hasn't really kicked off as of yet so youre looking at only 1500 content creators. 9/10 and i hope this game gets more publicity.

content:
Posted: April 8, 2015
												Alright, so I just spent the last forty hours building characters, running modules, and eventually creating my own... and that was only in the first six hours.     I've actually worked on industry RPGs and found the design engines too technical or too time consuming to put forth the efforts to make anything of my own.  The beauty of the editor here is that it's so user-friendly it's ENJOYABLE to operate, "and that has made all the difference."  Gameplay is simple but engaging and the interface to switch items between characters works perfectly with the altar to donate unwanted items for better ones.     The community has been friendly, helpful, and imaginative in their own designs.  The voting community is firm but fair for exploits and grinding modules, but the ability to update easily allows for quick edits and upgrades.       Keep an eye out for my work, I'm hooked!

content:
Posted: July 9, 2016
												Hack and slash RPG with focus on community-created maps. Fun to play with friends.The strong point on this game I think is the community maps--unlike Torchlight II, you can play the custom maps as soon as you finish the first level. The custom maps are very rich in varieties--ranging from simple hack and slash "kill the boss" map, to puzzle and crime investigation and campaign map. The great stuff is the community collaborates together in those custom maps, creating a series of maps with sequencial stories.Here are a few examples of those:


Advent Calendar 2015 
A Guide for Fight The Dragon
By: Astranon

			Celebrate the Christmas season with this collection of wintery adventures. Completed as a community project, this merry bundle is a gift for all to enjoy.		


http://steamcommunity.com/app/250560/discussions/3/412446292756896658/It's a pretty fun game to play with friends, but it should be noted that the game itself is pretty barebone: albeit having diverse loot (which gives you some different ways of combat), there is no skill tree. You have skill progression but there is no branch. So with only four classes (Fighter, Rogue, Fire Mage, Ice Mage) there aren't much abilities to be invested in. Also, there is no main storyline as the game relies heavily on custom maps.If you want a quick no-brainer hack and slash with very diverse levels and have several friends to play with, go get this game.

content:
Posted: March 29, 2014
Early Access Review
								A highly enjoyable game with lots of potential. This review is based on Early Access: Alpha 2.1. The concept of this game is simple, explore an array of user generated dungeons to acquire equipment and improve your character, currently only the Fighter & Fire Lord are available to play.The games combat system is simple and well defined, though I am not entirely comfortable with the controllers interface, I found myself continuosly trying to open( X ) an enemy rather than attack them. Perhaps allow for controller remapping, or provide a map that uses the Left/Right Triggers for combat?Enemy characters look exceptional and are initially enjoyable to slay, however after a few levels I found myself killing the same monsters with little variance in their combat tactics, most monsetrs operate on a run towards player and attack strategy.The game provides a swathe of equipment, with some rather enjoyable names, running through a dungeon can easily see your backpack being full of primarily junk items which you don't seem to be able to sell anywhere. In fact you can accumulate money but I'm not sure where you spend it?Dungeons can feel slightly bland with monsters only being used as the main challenge, hopefully as users become more familiar with the map-editor and the editor provides more tools to create unique set-pieces that provide memorable engagements this will be satiated.Overall I found the game exceptionally enjoyable to play, but as it is Early Access lacking some of the components that could make it a truly great game. I look forward to seeing more from the developer, 3 Sprockets.

content:
Posted: May 31, 2015
												I can only tentatively recommend Fight The Dragon as it stands right now.The game, when it behaves, is fun. Slashing or blasting your way through adventure after adventure is addicting, whether you're running through a new one or coming back to an old favorite for the thirtieth time because it's solidly made. The rewards for doing what the name of the game asks of you are nice, thought the timers are a bit irritating. The Adventure Creation Kit works just fine, as well. Which it should, because that's where Three Sprockets seems to be putting all their attention.Some weapons refuse to connect. The greatsword is the perfect example; the first two swings tend to miss. A lot. Even if the swing looks like it should have bisected your target. The axe also tends to catch air if you put it half an inch to the side of where the axe thinks it should be. Using these weapons WILL have you taking unnecessary hits. Projectile hitboxes are also an issue, with staff bolts impacting the guy next to your target, or the auto-target clinging to a mook because it happens to be a foot closer to you than your target.Then there's the platforming. It's weird, sticky, and slide-y. Relatively flat levels won't have the issue, or at least it won't be that noticeable. But, considering that the game is pretty much all community levels - and I won't be speaking to their quality here, it's not the place - there are going to be platforming challenges, even if the level description doesn't advertise it.Tip: ANGLE THE CAMERA.Make the jump straight forward. If you don't, there's a good chance you'll just 'walk' on the edge for a bit before the game gets bored and bounces you off into the abyss. Simple things like stairs can either be a little flavor added to a level or a fragmented turd unceremoniously pinched off from the♥♥♥♥♥♥of the Antichrist. You will - WILL, it's a guarantee - see your character fling themselves off into empty air because you turned around on a cliffside and got too close, or be attracted Nathan Drake-style to a climbable ledge precisely when you don't want to be.If Three Sprockets fixes the above - come on, guys, combat and movement are only TWO-THIRDS OF THE GAME - then I can fully recommend Fight The Dragon. As it stands now, only get it if you can handle the game not doing what you tell it to.

number of helpful: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 27, 2014
 Early impressions and a very cautious recommendation this is an early impression of fight the dragon, as such this "review" may change over time. however most if not all the mechanics of the game have been shown to me, and i'm really just playing through user created content now. This early impressions does not include co-op or the level editor, this is based purely on the single player experience Fight the dragon is a Community driven hack n slash RPG with tons of loot, played in an isometric top down sort of style. The main goal seems to involve level grinding up to attain better loot to fight the dragon, to get more loot so you can level grind more and eventually beat the dragon. This game has been quite a bit of fun to play so far however it becomes pretty repetitive pretty fast. I've put together a bit of list based on what i've seen so far and then catagorized them into a pros and cons sort of list. PROS  Nice, sleek, cute graphics works great with a controller (in fact i think i'd recommend a controller for this game) Tons of loot  A lot of levels to play through (i'm talking about over 9000 levels, though most seem to be beat-able within 5-10 minutes; which is a good or bad thing depending on your point of view) some nice puzzles and level design (depends entirely on the content creator) content seems to entirely come from the community, which is rather nice CONS  so far death has only come to me through sheer overwhelming numbers or falling off the map the combat system is very repetative, you have your normal attack, strong attack, dodge and about 4 magic spells (3 of which are unlocked through level progression), there is a bit of variety though with 4 classes to choose from but they all have what is mentioned above in terms of combat enemies are pretty much all the same and act the same except for a few speciality monsters (they just tend to run after you or if they're ranged they'll shoot at you however they always miss if youre moving around) there's not much to say in terms of combat tactics other than just kiting to stun and then using magic, you also have health and mana potions, but there's no in-depth, immersive combat to speak of. level progression seems rather slow overall combat is lack luster, it's enjoyable at first but because of its rather simple combat mechanics gets old rather quickly. Conclusion Fight the dragon offers a neat little hack n' slash supported entirely by a community, it offers a ton of loot and levels to play through. The game suffers from shallow repetitive combat that brings the overall experience down to knee deep level grinding while hunting for better loot to slay the dragon.overall i would only recommend this game if it's on sale due to it being rather repetitive in nature because of it's combat mechanics.

number of helpful: 8 of 13 people (62%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 8, 2014
Early Access Review
								Short version- Found a cardboard box, wore a cardboard box, got smashed by a dragon. A++I don't do reviews, but I feel a bit compelled to do one here because this game really could use more press. This is probably one of the best independent developments I've played, with (as far as I know) an almost entirely novel premise, given that  nearly all the content of the game will be community generated.It's already very fun in its current state. The mechanics are simple, very easy to pick up if you've played any recent isometric action RPGs. The controls are reasonably intuitive, and suit controller based play particularly well (although keyboard and mouse is perfectly viable). Combat is reasonably challenging and satisfying, with slightly more dependence on reflexes than other similar games. There are only a few fundamental puzzle mechanics at the moment- switch operation, pressure pads, key hunts and (interestingly) an autojump mechanic that is based on terrain height. That last mechanic, while seemingly restrictive, actually leads to some interesting puzzle design, and I've already seen it used quite well in some of the player made content.There's the odd bug or ten still, balance is a bit whacky, and some of the content that does need to be developer created (such as classes and items) is a little sparse at the moment, but this is both a great indie development and a very good quality early access in my opinion.

number of helpful: 11 of 19 people (58%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 28, 2014
Early Access Review
								The selling point to Fight the Dragon seems to be that it's the Little Big Planet of Hack n' Slash games. Sadly, if anyone really believes that statement, then they clearly don't understand what LBP is.The game itself is very bare bones and is very far away from having the complexity of LittleBigPlanet 1, let alone 2. Yes, it's currently in Early Access, but I am not seeing any promises of seeing any real depth being added to the game by the time it reaches 1.0.The gameplay is shallow at best. Sure, you have 4 classes and several abilities to boot, with both melee and ranged combat, but it's still just the bare minimum of what can be considered gameplay. After the first 5 levels played you WILL have seen 90% of the replay value this game could possibly offer. Hit enemies. Back off a bit to counter their grouping up on you. Hit them some more. Repeat forever. Activate an AoE skill once in a while not out of necessity but just for the sake of changing things up. So that's the gameplay aspect. But what about the user-created-content? Well, it suffers from two things in particular:1) The shallow, repetitive gameplay directly affects custom content. Simply put, there's only so little you can do with the creation tools that will make your time worthwhile, and those are mainly cosmetic things like the visual design of your map or the story/dialogue paired with it. 2)There's very few Logic-systems in the game to work with, and this is what separates this game from the likes of LBP. You are handed the tools to make a top-down hack n' slash dungeon and nothing else. You are creating maps for one very specific game. In LBP, you have the ability to create interesting platforming maps, combat, cutscenes and puzzles limitied almost entirely by your own imagination. You can make a map with a working Chess game complete with a functional AI who can Check-Mate you. Fight the Dragon doesn't even remotely come close to having that level of depth.Now a game isn't bad just because it's not LBP. I simply bring that up because it seems to be somewhat of a slogan for this game, and it's wrong. This game gets a thumbs down because it's shallow. Gameplay becomes boring in a matter of a couple hours and if you're a fan of user-generated-content, you've probably played/used numerous other software that puts this game's Editor to shame already.For now, this is being uninstalled for me, but I'll follow the developer to see if they have anything substantial up their sleeves. The only possible way I can recommend this game for now, is if you intend your young child or sibling to play it, as they will likely have the attention span required to have real fun with this game, due to simply not having experienced anything better.

content:
Posted: November 3, 2016
												I didn't expect to put so much time into this game when I opened it up. I didn't even know where I got the game in the first place. I've only been playing for less than a week and I recently checked my playtime and I was surprised to see that I had put over 40 hours into the game. I don't plan on stopping any time soon either.The game is a simple hack and slash with very basic mechanics that do tend to get repetitive and boring and somewhat tiring. I've only played the rogue with a crossbow so I can't speak for the rest of the characters, but I feel like they'd be pretty similar as well. You just kite everything until it's dead.The level up system is also very basic and pretty standard for an RPG. There isn't a huge variety of looks for weapons and armour, or even names as far as I can tell. Actually customization for your character includes different types of hair and clothes but not much else.The focus of the game is obviously to kill things, beat levels, and get stronger, like most other RPGs. But the main focus, and the selling point of this game in my opinion, is the user created levels and the level creator. The level creator is is very easy to learn and use (might take a little bit to get used to though due to the control scheme) and is capable of creating some very detailed and deep levels. I've spent most of my time making my own campaign and I'm loving that I can bring my stories to life. There have been multiple times where I'd queue up the spawn of many different entities and actions and I very much expected the game to either freeze or crash but I haven't seen even a drop in FPS. It runs surprisingly smooth. It's also very fun playing other people's levels and seeing what kinds of things they've come up with.All in all, the game looks and feels like it's in its early stages. I don't know whether or not it is or if there are plans for updates but it doesn't matter to me. What is displayed now is enough to keep my attention for hours and more being added in would only be a bonus.Great game.

content:

Early Access Review
								     I tried to hold off on buying this until it was further along in production, but I caved within a few days of discovering it. I have to admit, I was a little disappointed at first. There are some key features missing, e.g., a "loot shrine" to sell/buy goods, customization, etc. I also noticed a lack of music and sound effects (I'm not sure if this was due to a bug or not) sometimes while playing. The bugs are few and mostly managable, with the exception of one that somehow disables the "use" button. Of course, all this is to be expected in an early access game, and, to be honest, this is probably the most enjoyable early access game that I have played. From what I have seen, the developers are dedicated and very efficient with their updating of the game. If you're on the fence about it, but love the hack&slash and RPG genres, casual games, the idea of an easy-to-use adventure creation tool, and watching a game develop, go for it.

content:
Posted: February 17, 2016
												I give a very HESITANT Thumb-up. I'll explain.I can't really judge this as a game, as much as I have to judge it as a toolbox. And, as with any game where you hand the keys to the kingdom to the playerbase, only about 1 in 12 actually knows what they're doing. :(In Fight the Dragon you're given a battle arena against a red dragon with 1 MILLION health, and told to go questing from map to map to build yourself up and fight him. Any damage the dragon takes is cumulative, so even the 2 points of damage you do to him at lvl1 will stay.So, you leap from player-made map to player-made map, fighting monsters and finding loot. As I said, most folks should not be given the tools to make game levels, as they don't know what is appealing, what flows well or even what looks good. I found myself with serious respect for the real industry after playing 50+ maps (there's an achievement for that), and only really liking about 8 of them.But back to the dragon. Each time you finish a level you get a dragon ticket/scroll, which gives you three lives to fight the dragon in the special arena. As I said your damage sticks, so you run in and do as much damage as you can before he freaking annihilates you. Most battles last about 30 seconds, even with three lives. So you chip away at him over time as you level up Just remember:-Fire Resist does NOT work on the Dragon-You CANNOT bring your magic rings, arguably the best items in the game.-Almost all the dragon's attacks have major push-back, so good luck if you're a melee characterThe dragon fight is VERY unfair, and if that is the focus of your time in this game you're going to have a bad time. Instead, I spent my questing hours in search of a good map that felt like a real video game level, and not just something a 9 year-old threw together to mess with people. Not all levels are created equal, and it comes with a thumbs up/sideways/down function, and the ability to leave a comment on the level itself. I blasted a LOT of bad levels, trust me, and praised a few good ones.Fight the Dragon is a cute rpg toolbox, but if you judge by the player-made content, not an especially good game. Get it on sale for a quick distraction, but this is not something to devote to.TL:DR Version:-Dragon has 1 Million HP, you chip away at his health over many attempts.-Dragon fight does not respect fire resistance, magic rings, and allows you no health/mana items.-Dragon can kill you three times in under 40 seconds, burning your Dragon Fight attempt currency.-All the levels outside the tutorial are player-made, most of them are really bad.-Cute, addictive, but not something you're ever going to finish. Only the INSANE will grind away the hours to ACTUALLY slay the dragon.

content:
Posted: April 16, 2014
												Fight the Dragon is, in my opinion, one of the coolest game ideas that I have seen, and for the most part it is executed extremely. I originally bought this game in early access and was able to watch it grow, and grow it did. In FTD you create a character, choosing one of the four classes: Rogue, Fighter, Ice Wizard, or Fire Wizard. The classes themselves each have a unique feel to them and it is fun to check each of them out. There is a decent amount of abilities to choose from for each class and they all seem pretty fun to use. You can customize your character with the in-game models provided or you can download new, unique models from the Steam Workshop. Where the game truly shines is the ACK - Adventure Creation Kit. This allows anyone to use all of the assets in the game to create their own unique levels. Obviously some adventures turn out better than others, but there is a healthy amount of extremely creative individuals making adventures that are truly astounding. You create everything in your adventure from NPCs and their dialogue to the landscape and buildings. The most creative individuals have weaved some of the coolest stories I've seen in their adventures, and when you complete them you can even follow the creator to be updated whenever they create a new adventure. There are also measures to prevent creators from making adventures that just give you massive amounts of gear or treasure without doing anything, which is a good thing (why exploit a game, the point is to play and have fun)! Writing about it simply doesn't do it justice and it must be seen by your own eyes. Not everything in FTD is perfect though, in fact one of the largest parts of the game can be quite buggy and frustrating - the combat. You can play the game with a controller or KB/M, but when playing with either I still encounter many enemies that I simply swing at them several times without actually hitting them, even when they're right in front of me. This can lead to some VERY frustrating experiences. On one of my own adventures I created I ran into a bug where it was impossible for me to kill an enemy, and eventually I ended up being pushed off of the map. Reading other reviews it seems I'm not the only one that has had problems with the combat. Aesthetically the game isn't astounding, but the landscapes can sometimes be very pleasing. The soundtrack again isn't amazing, but there are a decent selection of tracks - you can even choose which will play in your adventure. Even further you can set "triggers" that will cue a certain track when an event happens (the ACK is amazing)!After logging 50+ hours in the game, and trudging through the frustrating parts I do have to still give it a thumbs up. The developers do pay attention to the community and they try and fix bugs pretty quick. Hopefully they will be able to fix the combat eventually, then this game would be a masterpiece, but for now I have give it an 8/10.TL;DR Game is really good except for some frustrating combat experience. Creative minds will enjoy making adventures.

content:
Posted: January 8, 2015
												I love Fight the Dragon!  I didn't think I would like it as much as I do.  I became addicted right away.  With almost all the levels being user created there is a ton of creative adventures to go on.  As more people find out about the game, more adventures will be made and there will be a seemingly limitless amount of adventures to explore.Creating adventures is quite simple and intuitive.  I made my first level (Rendlehelm Forest) within a few hours and it has some pretty cool features and looks pretty good.  The Steam Workshop items add a lot of options to the character customization, and I expect the options will get even better as more people make more complex pieces.The gameplay is very fun.  Old-school hack & slash with light RPG elements mixed in.  It is so simple yet so fun that I can play this with my young son, and my wife enjoys it too!  It's complex enough though, that I could easily play this with my gamer friends for hours and have a blast.The dragon is a lot of fun to fight too.  At first it seemed hopeless because the dragon is so powerful and you do so little damage.  However, as you level up and get more powerful you see the health finally start coming off in larger chuncks and you really feel like you are accomplishing something.  It's also really cool that it starts at 1,000,000 hitpoints and the damage done to it persists.  Talk about epic battle!  I'll be fighting this dragon for months.I highly recommend this game!  The more people that play and contribute the better it gets!

												This game is just realy realy funny. You can spend alot of hours at playing this game. And the best thing about playing it, you can do it whenever you want. You just start the game, play an adventure and quit again, if you feel so. On the other side, you can play it for a looong time if you want so. To fans of editors etc. Go ahead and buy it, it's worth it!

Early Access Review
								This game is great! At first I saw this and although the reviews seemed good, it just didn't seem like something I'd enjoy playing. Then I started playing it. This game hits so many of the right buttons it's fantastic. You want dungeon crawls, they got that. You want loot and charcater progression, of course they got that. You want a sandbox and build stuff, yeah they got that too. You want to play online with your friends, they got you covered there as well. I mean I have bought games for each of those reasons alone. To find a game that does all that, looks good, plays well, and has a great dev team...I don't know what your waiting for.  Oh are you looking at the User Created Adventures and thinking, "oh great a few good levels then a bunch of crappy super easy loot runs, and a ton of super hard death trap dungeons." Well let me stop you right there, because thats not the case at all. Most of the user created adventures I've played were very well balanced and a lot of fun. And using the ACK to make adventures is easy to learn and fun to play around with.  Now if your one of the many people on here that gets scared when they see "Early Access", don't worry over it. Honestly, you won't notice until update time when they add stuff. Thats right I said add stuff. More monsters, more ways to build adventures. So don't let the "EA" on the game scare you off.  In summery, great game, lots fun with a ton of variety.

content:
Posted: March 28, 2014
Early Access Review



YouTube™ Video: Fight the Dragon Alpha Review 

			Views: 3,487		

			Yeti's first game review is of "Fight the Dragon", a hack 'n' slash RPG with an emphasis on user-created content developed by 3 Sprockets, the team behind Cubemen.		

Fight the Dragon, even in its alpha state, is incredibly loaded and full of potential. The major RPG character archetypes aren't yet introduced as you only have the sword-and-board warrior and a fire mage, with a frost mage currently in development. The dungeon creation is incredibly simple yet powerful, allowing you to create nearly any environment and setup the details such as enemy patrol routes or which combinations of levers open a door.There are a couple dungeons created by 3 Sprockets, but they're mostly tutorial levels. The gimmick here is the user-created content. Dungeons created can be published and thrown into the pool of user-generated content, randomly chosen for an adventurer. There's filters you can set to get the newest dungeons or the highest-rated dungeons, and you can even set up a list of favorites.If you're afraid you'll "out-level" a dungeon, don't be. Difficulty and rewards scale with your character so you'll always get enjoyment out of your favorite dungeons. Now, you might say "Hey, if everything levels with me then how do I tell I'm really strong?" Cue the dragon.The dragon is a premade dungeon (bascially a door and a platform surrounded by lava) for you to head into from your house very early on. The dragon's health is absolutely insane - the chances of defeating him in one go are nearly impossible. It'll likely takes hundreds of attempts across all of your characters. The dragon's health never resets, so eventually you can defeat him, and as you try to your progress is logged. You're ranked against the world and ranked against your previous attempts, so you can see just how far you've come.I highly recommend this game to anyone interested in a dungeon-crawler. Diablo, Gauntlet, Torchlight - you name it, this game ranks right up there with them, even in it's alpha state.

content:
Posted: April 9, 2015
												Okay, so I love the fact that the levels are user made.  I love the nuanced fighting style with dodges, blocks , and stuns (making fighting more than just pumping out spells or spamming the attack button).  The graphics look great but are a llittle cartoony in my book.  I love creating little short stories for missions.  I've just put out an easy called "kill Jill", where Jack was pushed down the hill by Jill after the poisoned water in the well turned her into an evil creature.  And I have a medium one called "Ruin Runner" where you've been sent to rescue a woman from a bunch of criminals, and end up getting caught up in a treasure hunt in an old abandoned ruin.  And right now I'm working on one (don't have a title for it yet just search for creater named Dyztanz) where a town is overrun with evil when a hell gate opens up in a nearby mine.  That one is likely to be hard because it is so long.  It's a full fledged story with events and a big finale.Where was I?Ok, Pros...nice to look at.great fighting system.diverse character classes,Level creater is intuitive and easy to learnSome of the user created levels are innovative and brilliantFighting the dragon is a great little side game.Easily worth the money and more.(note I haven't even tried multiplayer yet)Consa little cartoony for me.some of the player created content is terrible and poorly thought out.the level creator could use more optons (more diversity in the npc types and enemy types)  That will probably be resolved over time as the developers are still adding contentIf you make a level with any sort of depth and length it is going to be labeled medium, hard or extreme, and unfortunately it seems that everyone goes for the easy missions.I have to work and cant spend all day playing and creating.pudding is better than yogurt.You haven't bought it yet.If you like Diablo style hack and slash, and have a controller, or you used to be a dungeon master and love creating adventures then this is a game custom built for you.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 1, 2015
												If you're looking at purchasing "Fight the Dragon", you are making a pretty wise investment with your funds.This title is a dungeon crawler, similar to the games like: "Diablo", but with a more light-hearted look and feel to it. However, there's a bit of a different twist to it. For, while you'll start off playing some basic developer created levels, to get aquainted with how the gameplay fully works, you'll soon find that the rest of the game is playing stages that other users have designed.This aspect, in itself, gives the game massive amounts of replayability. As there are new maps (and even campaigns!) being created, by people around the world, each and every day.But, sometimes, we don't want to play other people's levels. So, alongside the gameplay elements of this title, there is also a built-in level creator (Which you probably already guessed at, thanks to the above statements). And, my god is it a good one!The level creator gives you massive variety on what you can build with, and every tool that the developers used when making their stages as well. At first, it will feel a little overwhelming, as there are so many options to choose from, when looking at the blank canvas. However, the tools provided to you are so easy to learn that, as you practice (and play around) with them, you'll find yourself becoming more and more adept, and soon will be making stages that even the devlopers would be jealous of!All these good things said though, there are a few issues that I do have with the game.1 - The difficulty to this game is pretty low, once you get a single good weapon and piece of armor. Allowing you to solo "Extreme" difficulty stages, with little problem.2 - You can not fight the final boss (aka: the Dragon) in multi-player. Though, this was likely due to coding reasons, it still takes away a little bit from the feeling of an adventure, when most of the time, you're going to find yourself fighting through levels with your friends, or random allies.3 - The soundtrack isn't that varied, and is limited to maybe a total of 5 or 6 different tunes (Though, what little tracks there are, are still amazing).Despite these small issues I found with the game, "Fight the Dragon" is still an AMAZING game! One of which you'll find yourself putting many hours of your life into, just as I did when I played an almost non-stop 24 hour spree of the game.Yes. It's THAT addicting.Final Score: 8.5/10

content:
Posted: September 16, 2015
												This is a great little game! I've had a lot of fun with it so far. It's a very basic little ARPG with simple graphics and gameplay, but it manages to do a lot with a little. The simple graphics are charming and the simple gameplay actually has a surprising amount of depth once you get into it.Most of the adventures / maps you will play on are created by fellow players! There are tons of maps out there, and players are creating more and more each day. A lot of them are really fun!Adventure creation is where this game really shines. It comes pre-packaged with a very very easy-to-use adventure creation kit (ACK). I never like to even attempt to use these tools when they are packaged with other games because I am a re-tard! But this game's kit is so easy to use even a re-tard like me can create and publish adventures. It really is an awesome little kit.Is this game a Diablo killer? No way! But at $10 or whatever I paid for it, it is an excellent value.

												Fight the Dragon is beatiful little love letter to Diablo with its own unique charm.Is what I would say about the game if I needed a catchy hookline to reel people in, because they expect a well written review. Seriously though FtD is a very nice experience in the field of Dungeon crawling and with community creations/randomly generated levels it stays entertaining.You get 4 different classes, 1 of which I have personally played, that probably bring their own style of play with them. From what I have seen the melee battling is dank, albeit a bit strange at first due to the controls being built around your mouse cursor. (Sidenote : I'd like to be able to use my extra mouse buttons in the game, but I sadly cant)I also have yet to play the co-op mode of the game, but I am certain that it only adds to the fun.Fight the Dragon is totally worth a buy, especially if you're a fan of the already mentioned Blizzard title Diablo (or the much better and underated Dungeon Siege series excluding 3 Square why do you hate DS?)Now, if you excuse me, I have a Dragon to fight.Get it? Its the title of the game.

content:
Posted: September 27, 2014
Early Access Review
								I do reccomend this game to anyone who loves builders, things like garrys mod, space engineers, robocraft and the likes. There is plenty to work with in the map maker to eat up hours of your time and enough variety that you'll want to make every concievable type of map your head can come up with.I like the simplicity of it but it can get a little awkward at times when camera angles start to get in the way because of construction work and the lack of a multi level building mechanic at this time is a shame. However the map maker is a solid builder and even I found it easy to use.gameplay is just as simple and enjoyable but camera rotation can get a little annoying when you're in a big brawl and unless you spend a little time observing the game it can be a little difficult to understand the leveling mechanics. Honestly I still havent fully found everything on this yet but thats my own fault for jumping straight into the builder.so as a rundown.PRO's: simple, looks good, easy to control, vast possibilities for inventive maps, replayability due to community contributions.CON's: awkward camera movements, confusing insight on character mechanics (leveling, ability use, potion use).I've had this game a few days at the writing of this so I have yet to fully see everything it has to offer but this is what I have observed so far.

												I received the game as a gift on Dec 26th. In 6 days I've been "in the game" for over 67 hours. The majority of the time I was in the creation tool building dungeons. Hopefully they'll work on that, but they're still working some bugs out, so maybe they're still feature locked.

content:
Posted: June 20, 2014
Early Access Review
								Propably one of the best early access games I ever player.Since I buyed it some time ago there were tons of updates and new content. The community is quite active (considering it is early access!).Play it with your friends to maximize the fun and gaming experience.By having the possibilty to create your own adventures and share them with the public you get the feeling of being a small part of the game itself. And of course you can also play your or your friends maps together.There are a few maps, generated by the programmers to help new players but you will most of the time enjoy maps created by other players.So if you like bashing through almost random levels and exploring dungeons created by users or generating your own adventures and levels you should give "Fight The Dragon" a try.If you expect a story-based rpg where you don't have (or be able) to enjoy your own interpretation of a story or a realistic adventure you should not buy this game.The story, as I said, is created by the user and you will see by the looks of the pictures that for instance the fighting system is not comparable to the one of for example dark souls.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 26, 2014
Early Access Review
								Fight the Dragon is a  very nice mini-hack&slash game where you play through several maps that have been created by the community. And I have to say that there are some really nice maps that are fun to play. But there are also maps that aren't thought out so well. But you (and the rest of the community) votes on the map and you can decide to only play maps that have a high community rating. Some people have really interesting ideas for their maps so this game never gets boring.If you expect a storyline in this game, you won't find any because this is not about long-spanning adventures but more about dungeon-runs that do not take that much time. So, if you have a busy life, it's easy to fit in a FtD session inbetween your busy schedule.The level editor is also very nice and intuitive. It's really not surprising that the number of maps for this game has exploded.So, who should buy this game? You should buy this if you like-Hash and Slash games (like Diablo)-Looting and equipment management.-Building your own maps/dungeons and share them-Multiplayer gaming with your friends-fighting hordes of monsters with weapons and spells-solving puzzles (in some maps)Things you might expect but that are not there:-Skilltrees. Each class has a fixed set of abilities that unlock at specific levels-A storyline. But future updates might allow map creaters to link maps to create more epic adventures-Item trading (but you can drop items ingame for your friends)-Always a dark atmosphere like in Diablo. Some maps are dark and menacing, but sometimes the overall visual style is a bit too non-threatening. While the graphics are not as spiffy as in Diablo, I think 3sprockets has done a good job with the visuals.A note for Linux users: There is a thread in the game's forum about systems that are capable of running the game. I'm playing this game just fine with Intel graphics. So check out the thread to see if someone with a similar computer managed to run the game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 18, 2014
Early Access Review
								                                    I don't normally write reviews but for FtD had to make an exception.   I know a fair amount of people dread early access games, but the devs working on FtD have something special going on. They are straightforward on what the game is and what they intend to do. They listen and respond to the community and have implemented things that have been suggested. They just have a generally nice vibe about them that is enjoyable.   The game itself is lite RPG: the stats won't blow your mind and the gear slowly scales as you level. There are 4 skills per class and 4 classes also a level cap of 40 at this moment. Online/lan/splitscreen local multiplayer arleady in the game and supports the use of controllers. The Hack and Slash elements are well implemented for an Alpha build and is in a very playable state. There are still some bugs to be ironed out and features to be added in but saying that the game still is a ton of fun.  The best feature I would have to say is the ACK (adventure creation kit). I have spent at least 1/2 my time playing this game in ACK making adventures. There are still a lot of features to be added like more monsters and more triggers (atm it is only implemented for weather effects) but you can still make some decent adventures given enough time and effort.This game seems like it's flying under the radar but I highly enjoy the game and highly recomend it. It has a lot of potential and looking forward to it!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 27, 2014
												Fight the Dragon is a hack-n-slash RPG-lite. The game is centered around custom-content. Things like custom heads, hair, and levels. The customization only goes so deep, though. This leaves custom levels feeling shallow.The game has a large identity issue. There are several poorly explained and poorly used mechanics that are only there to make the game feel more like other games. For instance, some weapons require you to have a certain level to equip. This is fine and good, and it fits the gameplay very well. The game complicates this by adding skill-points that you unlock everytime you level up. This would be fine if it gave you more than 1 skill point per level, but instead your left with a restricted and overly complicated leveling system. It ruins the flow when you pick up an awesome weapon, only to find that you don't have high enough Luck or Strength to wield it.Combat is your traditional "Click-Click-Click-Heal-Click" style of combat. It has the illusion of deepness, giving each class unique heavy attacks. These heavy attacks all boil down to about the same thing. You throw something, and in a second or two it explodes. Not a very original combat system, but it works well.Customization is a mixed bag. You can customize the textures of your body, head, and hair. Basic stuff, not very hard to grasp at all. For more advanced people, you can customize the meshes of only the head and hair. This frustrates me a bit, but it doesn't really affect my view on the game.The level editor is frustrating as hell. The controls require you to forget everything you know about good level editors, because none of it transfers over. Basic stuff is just omitted for no reason. Overall, the game is fun. As of writing, I've put in about 4 hours into the game. 3 of which were spent on multiplayer. It's a little boring, but if you get it on sale it isn't bad.

content:
Posted: April 17, 2016
												After I became intrigued about this game when I heard it was like Little Big Planet, one of my favorite PS3 games. A few questions later and I bought the game. Now 4 hours into the game I am proud to say that I bought this game. It is fun, unique and "never ending" but I'll get to that later. You create your character from one of the 4 classes. You can customize their skin and even customize it with some cool skins made with the steam workshop. After you do that they drop you into the hub where you will spend a lot of time "praying" to the gift gods and managing your inventory. From here you may go to online mode (multiplayer), go on an adventure or battle the dragon which requires a dragon scroll. Once I beat the developer made levels it started to put me into community made levels which made me nervous but it turns out that the devs don't like garbage levels polluting their game. Which is good. At this point I realised that this game is "never ending" because you can create your own adventures or play other adventures after you played the developer ones.The level creation tool deserves more credit than it gets as you can do a lot with the triggers and events. Sadly I have not tried to play this with multiplayer so I cannot give a review on that.Pros:Lots of good unique levelsLevel editorCharacter customizationNice graphical feelCons:I can see how some people can find this game repetative.Games this is similar to:Spiral Knights and (barely) Little Big Planet. More so to spiral knights.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 24, 2014
Early Access Review
								Fight the Dragon is a fun little hack n' slash with very basic, Gauntlet-style gameplay. The game is entirely built around player made levels and designed to be played in short bursts, with each level lasting 15 minutes on average. The four available classes are differentiated by each having 4 abilities (in addition to basic attacking), as well as some unique weapon types that are only useable by certain classes.The lack of combat depth may turn some people off but it comes down to personal preference. The adventure creator is easy to use and offers a lot of freedom, with more content being added on a regular basis. At the time of this writing, they've even begun adding a logic system to the creator as well. The game is great for picking up and running through some adventures in your down time where as making levels can keep you busy for hours on end.FTD isn't perfect and has it's issues. The entire game's entertainment value relies on the quality of maps and the variety of tools available to those who make the maps. That being said, the devs are very attentive and really seem to care about making the game better and better. They listen to community feedback and continue to polish and add to the game, pushing out great patches on a quite regular basis. Overall I don't see much to complain about. The game is a fun little gem to spend time in and has the potential for a lot of replayability. I look forward to seeing FTD grow and hopefully its community will as well.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 18, 2016
												I give this a thumbs up, but only because it is priced at about the right level for the content you can expect. In terms of gameplay, you work your way through hack and slash isometric maps, collect gear and loot, which you either equip or exchange for stat gains or better gear. Completing maps earns you tickets to "Fight The Dragon". The maps usually involve a lot of clicking and running, as well as puzzles revolving largely around pressure pads and levers hidden within maze-like environments. Fighting the dragon is simply an arena against a boss. This is reasonably fun for a short period of time, but it has little longevity. The best part of the game is the creator, where you can design and build your own maps and campaigns. Despite the limiting graphics, there is actually a lot of freedom to build from the ground up, create relatively complex puzzles and interesting environments. Unfortunately, as always with these games, the maps you produce tend to get lost amongst a lot of crap, or go unnoticed beside those few early maps that received "thumbs ups" so show up in most people's searches.     I give this a tentative recommendation. It is fun but has little longevity.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 12, 2015
												Fight the Dragon is a community driven hack n' slash rpg created by 3 Sprockets, where all the maps are created by other community members using the built in adventure construction kit. Playing as one of three classes, (warrior, mage, or rogue) you can team up with up to three other people, or head in solo and delve into trap filled dungeons,  explore haunted ruins, save a beloved tavern, or any of a hundred other ideas your fellow players can devise.  All so you can gather loot and  gain power in order to defeat the ultimate of all bosses - the mighty dragon!Over all the game is incredibly of fun,  with tons of replay-ability in the form of  user-created maps. You have the ability to create/join a random pick-up group, if you don't have friends available to play with, and in my limited experience the game does a pretty good job at grouping you with similarly leveled characters. The game can be played with either keyboard and mouse or controller; I recommend using the controller to play, and the keyboard and mouse to create maps with, as the controls in the construction kit felt a bit clunky to me.My playthrough of a map:

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 9, 2015
												Okay, so I love the fact that the levels are user made.  I love the nuanced fighting style with dodges, blocks , and stuns (making fighting more than just pumping out spells or spamming the attack button).  The graphics look great but are a llittle cartoony in my book.  I love creating little short stories for missions.  I've just put out an easy called "kill Jill", where Jack was pushed down the hill by Jill after the poisoned water in the well turned her into an evil creature.  And I have a medium one called "Ruin Runner" where you've been sent to rescue a woman from a bunch of criminals, and end up getting caught up in a treasure hunt in an old abandoned ruin.  And right now I'm working on one (don't have a title for it yet just search for creater named Dyztanz) where a town is overrun with evil when a hell gate opens up in a nearby mine.  That one is likely to be hard because it is so long.  It's a full fledged story with events and a big finale.Where was I?Ok, Pros...nice to look at.great fighting system.diverse character classes,Level creater is intuitive and easy to learnSome of the user created levels are innovative and brilliantFighting the dragon is a great little side game.Easily worth the money and more.(note I haven't even tried multiplayer yet)Consa little cartoony for me.some of the player created content is terrible and poorly thought out.the level creator could use more optons (more diversity in the npc types and enemy types)  That will probably be resolved over time as the developers are still adding contentIf you make a level with any sort of depth and length it is going to be labeled medium, hard or extreme, and unfortunately it seems that everyone goes for the easy missions.I have to work and cant spend all day playing and creating.pudding is better than yogurt.You haven't bought it yet.If you like Diablo style hack and slash, and have a controller, or you used to be a dungeon master and love creating adventures then this is a game custom built for you.

content:
Posted: July 5, 2014
Early Access Review
								First a quick result: 8.5/10, the game is definitely worth the price.  FUN to play both in SOLO mode and Multiplayer mode.The game looks promising, has a few glitches but I am literally still suprised as many other early access games have many glitches and options ingame are limited.The main idea is go on adventures to gain dragon scrolls, loot and xp to get enough power to defeat THE DRAGON SOLO.Fight The Dragon is still in early access but still manages to impress me in many ways. Firstly, the game has a variety of skills and classes such as a firelord, fighter. It also has a variety of weapons, armour and special skills that requires you to be in a specific class BUT NOT TO WORRY SINCE YOU CAN CREATE MORE THAN ONE CHARACTER. The leveling up mechanics is impressive and it makes sure that gaining XP isn't easy nor hard. The system it uses to go on adventures(or dungeons) is all based on other player's creation. EVEN YOU CAN MAKE A MAP and have it featured.The cons are the few glitches and the servers are generally mediocre and you cannot host locally YET. THE GAME GETS MANY PATCHES( 0~90 Mb) and everytime there's an update, I get more impressed. More features are still being developed, so expect the game to get more interesting and fun.IMO, it is worth the money and future looks promising :-)

												Despite all of its flaws, this is still one of my favorite games to play with my friends. There is so much fun to be had just exploring and plundering the various missions and dungeons that people have made for this game, ranging from open-world style exploration minions to dungeon crawling and boss rushes. The level editor is simple and easy to use, with the ability to build story into them with NPCs and whatnot giving the game ridiculous longevity.The game isn't perfect, though. The UI takes a little bit of getting used to, and the combat is pretty lacklustre. Not to mention the game's survival is dependent on the support of its player base.TL;DR version:Pros:- Lots of variety in levels- Great to play with friends- Finding new loot is addictive and exciting- Good variety in the different classesCons:- Combat leaves a bit to be desired- Can't easily search for specific levels to play with friends

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 23, 2015
For fellow playersThis game is worth playing if you enjoy any sort of fantasy hack&slash. Gauntlet* and Hammerwatch are the comparisons that come to mind. WIth community driven content and online multiplayer, the re-playability of this game is very high. It's not without it's bugs or faults, but the developers are also active on the forums and within the community; They are quick to address concerns the playerbase has with the game, replying frequently to questions posed by the community. The Workshop content is also a nice touch, allowing much more customization of your character than offered by the vanilla game; Levels, though, are found in game and not on the Workshop.The editor is simple and uncomplicated (as much as an editor can be), but don't expect to be able to do too much with it. There are some nice adventures out there, but this isn't Little Big Planet. It does what it says on the box, and hopefully the devs add more to it as time goes by (and I believe they are?).Play this game with a controller as playing with the keyboard requires a bit of hand contortion, or quick relfexes and finger accuracy, to access all the controls.*: I've played classic Gauntlet and Gauntlet Legends, but not the newest remake on Steam. From what I understand, though, it is still an apt comparison.For the devsWhile I assuredly like and recommend this game it definitely needs that something more to make me love it.Difficulty indicators on the world map don't appear to mean a damn thing; I've played Easy maps that overwhelmed me right out of the gate and I've played Extreme maps that were a cakewalk.I really wish you could read the description of a level before starting it.Ranged enemies are a balance issue and when more than 2 or 3 are nearby it almost takes the fun away.I also wish the editor was a bit more robust. You can't move props you've already placed, instead you have to delete and remake them. Variables and flags would also be a godsend, especially if values could carry over between maps in a campaign (Imagine if later maps could be changed depending on choices earlier in the campaign!). It could also use a bit more variety: pressure plates that don't have large skulls on them and are easier to hide, a variety of switches (perhaps even hidden ones, like wall sconces or torches), pressure plate triggers that aren't barrels... Things that allow the community to really dig their nails into and get creative with. Right now it all feels a little cookie cutter.

content:
Posted: August 9, 2015
This is a fairly fun, albeit generic, multiplayer dungeon romp. It gets serious points for player made levels, and well done multiplayer. Essentially, anybody can host a game, and it is easy. There is a 'hub' where you can store items and manage your player's stuff, which is really well done. You then venture out into the world as a team.Pros:+Very customizable characters+Fairly tight controls+Crisp graphics+Great controller supportCons:-Feels really generic as far as textures and levels, but I assume this is what you get when custom level building is so easy-Music is meh-There should be an option for larger text when playing on your television - currently its way to difficult to read from the couchIf you have friends that are into RPG dungeon romps, you can't go wrong here.

content:
Posted: July 5, 2014
Early Access Review
								First a quick result: 8.5/10, the game is definitely worth the price.  FUN to play both in SOLO mode and Multiplayer mode.The game looks promising, has a few glitches but I am literally still suprised as many other early access games have many glitches and options ingame are limited.The main idea is go on adventures to gain dragon scrolls, loot and xp to get enough power to defeat THE DRAGON SOLO.Fight The Dragon is still in early access but still manages to impress me in many ways. Firstly, the game has a variety of skills and classes such as a firelord, fighter. It also has a variety of weapons, armour and special skills that requires you to be in a specific class BUT NOT TO WORRY SINCE YOU CAN CREATE MORE THAN ONE CHARACTER. The leveling up mechanics is impressive and it makes sure that gaining XP isn't easy nor hard. The system it uses to go on adventures(or dungeons) is all based on other player's creation. EVEN YOU CAN MAKE A MAP and have it featured.The cons are the few glitches and the servers are generally mediocre and you cannot host locally YET. THE GAME GETS MANY PATCHES( 0~90 Mb) and everytime there's an update, I get more impressed. More features are still being developed, so expect the game to get more interesting and fun.IMO, it is worth the money and future looks promising :-)

content:
Posted: December 28, 2014
												I generally don't like hack'n'slash games, but this one is really good. The best thing about it is that you never know what lies ahead, because the game comes with enough player-made maps to never play the same map again and still spend hundreds of hours playing it.It could be better only if it had co-op...wait, it has! It's really easy to connect with your friends and explore dungeons together, which is even more fun, I wish we could kill the Dragon co-op too (dragon killing is solo-only activity currently).So the game is 100% worth the money (and is far more entertaining than, say, Diablo III imho).

content:
Posted: May 28, 2015
												I can't help but love Fight the Dragon.It's Diablo without the hassle. It's a game with core mechanics so simple you can understand them within minutes. It's you and some friends wading through a challenging adventure which likely none of you have seen before.If I wanted a deep fantasy RPG with strong characters and a thick plot, I'd go and play Dragon Age. What we have here is something very different – a game that you can pick up and play without all of that traditional RPG baggage. Grab a few friends, hit 'random level', and give it a go. I challenge you not to have fun.Read my full review here: http://www.hookedgamers.com/pc/fight_the_dragon/review/article-1386.html

content:
Posted: April 29, 2015
												I'm in love with this game, and I had no intention of buying it. I trader just offered this game, I never heard of it, so I looked at some lets plays and I accepted the trade. I was gonna keep it for profit but I really wanted to play it, so I added it to my library, and I'm glad I did. Go trough hundreds of user generated levels, get some dragon scrolls and once you think you are ready, then you can fight the dragon, hence the name.Don't Worry, you don't need to kill the dragon, I don't know if you need to last long enough or do as much damage before you die, but whatever it is. You get good reward that can only be obtained from fighting the dragon. I'm sure you get the best rewards by killing the dragon, but I'm only level 6. That will take HOURS before I can kill it. The user generated levels are great. There are 2 categories. Adventure and Campaign. Campaign is just like adventure but with more indepth story and multiple levels.The only negative thing I can say right now is the multiplayer.. If you could call it that.  There are barely anyone online (about 0-4, in a good day), and most of the people online are level 60+ and as beginner, that will completely remove the challenge and fun from the game. Luckily, when hosting your game, you can put a minimum and a maximum levels that can join you, but no one would join because there are almost no people online. That's not the devs fault though. ITS YOUR FAULT FOR NOT BUYING THIS GAME!! BUY IT NOW!

												Wow.My first look in this game felt like it would be "lego-ish", if that makes any sense. Turns out it wasn't. Just like promised, Diablo and LBP combined. It has the classic Hack & Slash feeling in it, yet making it fun to play as there's so many player-made maps, and most of them are fun to play.Every class has it's own unique skills and abilities. They are quite balanced, except for the Fighter. The game is heavily based on ranged combat (i'm not saying that CQB would suck or anything) mainly because when you have to fight even a little bit bigger groups they do alot of damage to you if you try to melee them. CQB works quite well against single enemies, but ranged weaponry is more effective against groups and bosses.Overall, i'd say this game is awesome and fun to play :)

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 12, 2014
Early Access Review
								Early Access Review:First let me point out that Fight The Dragon is fun and addictive. Once you start getting some better gear and how the game plays, you'll be hooked for hours.In a nutshell, Fight The Dragon is an isometric ARPG where you hack and slash your way thru bandit camps, dungeons and graveyards. You pick up loot and level up your character. But that's where the twist of the game comes in. These levels you'll go thru are user-created, which means other players like yourself, created them. Level creation is another aspect of the game as you are given the ACK(Adventure Construction Kit) which allows you to design your own level, may it be a pillaged town or a dark and gruesome dungeon. ACK works like a 3D modeling software. There are a lot of tools that you can play around with and you can design the dungeon to your own liking, and I mean a lot, you can put traps, enemies, build rooms, put up decorations, set up puzzles and many more, the sky is the limit. This on the other hand have a downside to it such as other players tend to make troll maps.The leveling system of the game is the usual as you get experience points from killing mobs and bosses, and the equipment system is typical. On the other hand, they present these systems with a clean and sleek designed hud which is a good touch and a great help to user experience.You can replay old dungeons if you wanna grind to get better gear and experience as everything follows to your level. and same with new characters.And with the title, you get to fight The Dragon ofcourse, after you level and gear up, there's a seperate instance where you can go in and fight The Dragon. The Dragon has huge life points but damage carries over even after death. This is a great way to see how much damage you can make and see the improvements of your new gear. As of the moment though, defeating The Dragon has no rewards yet, but this is understood since the game is still in Alpha.On the side note though, the game feels it lacks sounds as if you turn the music down, you won't really hear anything other than the "thud" that your weapon makes when it hits an enemy, which to my opinion also lacks kick.Overall, Fight The Dragon is a must have title for fans of the genre and dungeon master sims as well. I personally will follow how the game progresses and hope that it's for the better, With 1418 maps(and counting) and the ACK, you'll be amaze how creative and very imaginative other players can be. You'll surely spend hours with Fight The Dragon.

Early Access Review
								To the Dev's,Guys, we need a way to respond to feedback in-game from players who've run through our maps.  Also, the search mechanism for choosing adventures needs work.  There have been several complaints about not being able to search for maps based on user defined tags.  Further, it seems only the top rated maps are visible to players when they're searching for adventures to run.  How can an adventure rise to the top of the ratings if no one can find it?  Please fix these issues so that we are incentivized to continue adding content and telling our friends about this, otherwise, gem of a game!Respectfully,The Rebel Raven

Early Access Review
								What makes Fight The Dragon really special - and the reason I purchased it - is its adventure editor (i.e. level editor). If you have always dreamt of building small fantasy adventures, this will be your dream come true. It is so intuitive to use that anyone can be super creative with it, regardless of your techcred.As for the game, it is a cute ARPG that may satisfy those who have always wanted to try that kind of game withouth delving into (insert your favourite ARPG here). It is pretty basic but fun for 10 min sessions.But, really, it is the editor that makes it. It will be interesting to see how much power and flexibilty we get when the game releases, without loosing the amazing accessibility.Now if you'll excuse me, I will jump back in and build one of my most memorable Dark Souls moment and get fellow players to suffer through my levels, but in more blocky form.

content:
Posted: June 30, 2014
Early Access Review
								If all you could think about while slaying your way through Diablo, Dark Alliance or Torchlight was, "I wish there was a game that let me make my own dungeons and adventures," then this is the game for you.Well, sort of. Fight the Dragon is made for dungeons that take less than a half hour to complete, and the terrain and dungeon-building tools are very Lego or Minecraft-esque. They're still smoothing out the combat (which takes more cues from Gauntlet than modern ARPGs), adding more tilesets and enemies, and developing more classes. But it's a thoroughly pleasant experience for an Early Access game. The dungeon-building is intuitive and well-developed, even at this stage. Updates and regular and substansial, and the developers respond to player feedback. Highly reccomended, especially if, like me, you enjoyed the park builder in Tony Hawk's Pro Skater or the dungeon builder in Neverwinter more than the actual game.

content:
Posted: August 2, 2014
Early Access Review
								Great little game so far! At its heart, it's essentially DnD, as all of the adventures you play are made by the community, which all are unique in that you have freedom over the entire layout, theme, loot locations, and even NPC dialog. Even better, you can tag along with friends and adventure together, everyone getting their own loot drops.You can choose from 4 classes at the moment: Warrior, Fire Lord, Ice Wizard and Black Rogue. You obtain experience and levels and loot as you play through random adventures made by your fellow players and friends. The "item vendor" is actually a "Loot Shrine" that you offer unwanted items to, build up points which slowly fall into higher and higher tiers that grant you better and better items when you "pray" to the loot shrine. On top of that, it's also your loot stash (ie. cross-character).The ACK (Adventure Construction Kit) is quite easy and effective to work with, already supporting Environment Effects, Time of Day, water/lava/mud, copy/paste (but not undo yet, sadly), with things like music, mutators and map triggers all on the way! The current set of assets isn't overwhelming, but not completely barren either. It also has fledgling "room-over-room" support in the form of some pretty basic bridges, which will hopefully be expanded as time goes on.In summary, I'm really liking this game so far. Given the fact that the adventures are entirely community made, there's always something new to do, and more loot to find!
