content:
Posted: November 18, 2014
Early Access Review
								After about 6 hours of playing the game, i think i have a pretty decent feel on where it stands and how it works ^_^This game is 99% user created content and that can go both ways. your experience can either be fantastic or dreadful depending on the community maps you get. In MY experience i have had very few maps that i hated and quite honestly most of the maps are actually really good!lets get into the pros and cons!Pros:-easy to use level creation kit-game is great for both short and long play sessions-will have steam workshop content in the future (ie skins and other customization features)-very fun multiplayer-its gauntlet meets little big planet!Cons:- the movement can be a little odd to get used to at first, it feels rather stiff- the evasion mechanic can use some work as it will NOT interrupt your current attack. your choice is either tank to deal damage or evade to do none- spell casters in the game still feel like melee classes, this here is a huge problem for me because it makes it feel like the game caters to more tanky characters (ie warrior)-some levels you recieve are outright horrible/cannot be completed (however you CAN delete the map, exit, and block the creator/map from showing up again!)All in all, i would say this game is a must buy if you were EVER a fan of gauntlet or little big planet. you are given a lot of freedom with the in game creation kit, and with the steam workshop and further development i see a real gem on our hands.As long as they sort out that evasion issue and make the caster classes a bit more diverse, AND add some more creatures and tile-sets to the game (or at least allow us to via steam workshop) this game has insane potential. 8/10 (score can improve with further development)

content:
Posted: October 28, 2014
Early Access Review
								The game is at it's core a Hack N Slash game and it's done quite well.Though I feel the focus is put where it's needed most, the Adventure Creation Kit and it's obvious.It's easy to use and after using it for the first time, I published by first map for it "Razghul Crypt" and I continued to change things about it that I didn't like about it.And as time has gone on, I've gotten better with using the ACK and published several other levels and even made a campaign all within the space of a week.And as it stands I enjoy not only making content, but playing other peoples creations as well.2/10/15There have been several incredible improvements to the editor with being able to set up better puzzles and a few more enemy types each with their own use.When I originally had created this review I didn't expect much work to be put into it, but I didn't care at the time because I enjoyed making levels for people.But now, I'm not as active as I previously was with updating and creating levels, but I check in every so often to read comments people leave on my levels and see where I'm placed on the leaderboard.

content:
Posted: January 3, 2016
												Playing as a warrior is so dreadfully dull that I'd rather go play a sports game, and I haven't played a sports game of my own volition since probably Tecmo Bowl on the NES.Pros:-Workshop support-Multiplayer (didn't try it, though)-Create your own contentCons:-Base content is dreadfully paced and not very exciting-Weak character creation options without utilizing workshop content-Terrible interface; the inventory menu is one of the worst I've ever seen-Terrible controls for most aspects of the game, including inventory management-Terrible tutorial expalining how things like the shrine work (I'm assuming I can only donate once an adventure)-Combat (at least for warriors) is mostly just clicking in place until you or your aggressors are dead-Aiming in combat is kind of wonky, and the animations don't really adjust mid swing, so you're often swinging at air-Jumping and climbing is cumbersome at pointsFinal Thoughts:Why would you put a station (a backpack) near your house to access your inventory? It literally just hits tab for you. You can access your inventory anywhere, it just doesn't look like one. Just play Diablo, Torchlight, Minecraft or anything else.

content:
Posted: December 24, 2016
												I have played about 5 levels so my opinion may not be totally accurate, but I already got a decent grip of how the game works.This game is great when got during a sale (my case). It's relatively fun, the community creation aspect and etc is a big plus, but the combat is kinda clunky for a Hack n' Slash. I found myself waving my weapon at nothing at many times, and the play with mouse + keyboard seem much worse than with a controller, I think a controller recomendation should be there. *However if you press the movement keys on the same direction the mouse is pointing at while striking, it does seem (at least seem) to improve accuracy.Also, despite having quite simplistic graphics, I have both a gaming computer and a notebook, and I found myself shocked to notice that the notebook couldn't run above 30 fps, actually not even above 20. It's an i3 with 4 gigs of memory, and the video card isn't really great, but it plays Dota 2 really well with almost moderate graphic settings. Not being able to run this game just seems... wrong. * NOTE I put the game in the lowest settings and now things are pretty smooth, at least with small mobs so far, but to me it is still weird that Dota 2 on some average aspects still runned smoother. Anyways at least you will probably play the game decently with just a little better than minimum specs.*Anyway I'm not sure if I would recommend this game for full price, but if you are looking for a new way of experiencing old concepts from action rpg-like games, this one will probably keep you entertained for quite some time. I just wish the hitboxes and optimizations were, (I may be wrong here but that's how I felt) better. Still, I think I found myself a new timekiller.

The missions did not carry over from when I joined my friends lobby and did like 15 and the gameplay does get a little repetetive. With all of these things considered, I should not have a problem putting over twenty hours onto this game.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 30, 2014
Early Access Review
								I try to keep my fascination with video games under wraps..it's such a loaded topic it makes religion and politics look positively benign. Some things are just too hot to discuss on social media.And as much as I love dungeon crawlers and space games, I have to admit they usually don't hold my interest. World of Warcraft was an exception, but after leveling five characters to 80 my heart just wasn't in it any more.I like to MAKE things, not just play with things other people made..no matter how cool they are. No dungeon crawling fulfills me like painting does, no space battles are as challenging as writing a good song.With Fight the Dragon that may have changed..This is a game that you make yourself.Sure, there are hundreds of levels already made, but you have access to the exact same editor the developers use. Build your dungeon brick by brick. Devise devious traps, puzzles, and mazes. Populate your level with enemies ranging from fire beetles to skeleton archers, each with their own behavior and AI.Make pools of lava, poison, or mud. Rivers of water and bridges with trapdoors. Gates that open if you find the right key. Pressure plates that trigger walls of fire. NPCs that guide the player along their way.Then when you finish making your level, you can publish it. Your level will be played and voted on by other Fight the Dragon players around the world.It's much more fun to make a game than to play a game, and if your kids are into games but you worry that it's not an intellectually stimulating pursuit, you might do well to buy them a copy of Fight the Dragon.And if you're like me and tend to like the idea of games more than games themselves, buy it for yourself. Spend a few hours in video-game legoland and I'll bet you'll be as excited as I am.We finally have the keys to the castle!

number of helpful: 4 of 8 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 22, 2014
												As a level editor, Fight The Dragon is excellent, with simple, easily understood UI and an intuitive map editor.As a diablo-style RPG, the game severely lacks content, story, or skill progression.  It's too easy to find levels that use every monster/mechanic in the game, which leads to everything afterwards feeling repetive. So after 4 or 5 levels or shooting/slashing mobs, collecting keys, and placing barrels on switches to open doors, it gets quite dull. If you're looking for a chance to make your own (short) RPG dungeons to show off to your friends, this is a fine game to pickup.  But, if you're looking to play through a MP adventure with friends, well, you're better off sticking with games that advertise their game, not their editors.

number of helpful: 5 of 10 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 3, 2015
												It's a dungeon crawler type game where everything scales to your level. Enemies gain health and damage as you level up; you gain health and damage as you level up; the higher your level the higher quality gear that drops; the Dragon hits harder the higher level you are... everything scales with your level. The only variance in this game is the difficulty category of the map. Easy maps will always be easy and hard maps will always be hard... end of story. The loot and xp grinding gets old and tired when your reward is basically a higher number and new loot to grind so that you can pass through levels with the same ease as you could at your prior level. Good for a couple hours of entertainment, but once you realize you aren't actually getting stronger it's stale.

number of helpful: 4 of 8 people (50%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 7, 2015
												This is my first review, but I feel like i need to write this.This game is good and fun to play, but for a group of 4 this game is really easy, there is player made content cool! There are different monsters and RNG loot, cool! But the game lacks in difficulty, the game is a steamroll after level 5 and gives no challenges, this is a huge issue in my eyes. Also when creating maps you are limited with height options, making mountain maps impossible, and maps are made to be linear, limitations are bad in my opinion, and mob creating is also pretty lame, you cant create cool bosses with high health and damage, and the skills for bosses are lacking because there are none.If you want a cool game for 2-5 hours this is it, but for more its impossible. Need a lot of polish and tweaks to be a good game.

number of helpful: 4 of 8 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 17, 2015
												This game gets boring after a while. There's a few hillarious bugs in the game that made me laugh my head off, but that's basically the best part. There are some very challenging and fun dungeons, but most of them are easy as heck, even though they shouldn't be. Why? Crossbows. You basically just need a crossbow and some decent juking strats and kiting strats if things get out of hand, because crossbows can stun enemies. They're basically unbalanced. Also, Fighting the Dragon is kinda boring. It has 4 basic moves that you can all dodge easily except for one of them, and 2 op abilities that can half shot you at level 15ish that you can dodge easily. There's also a bug that you can get while fighting the dragon, maybe in dungeons too. If you stand still and just use basic attacks, the dragon will keep attacking you until you get down to 1 hp. Then, for some reason, the game shows the dragon doing damage, but it actually doesn't and you become virtually immortal unless you use a heavy attack, special move, or you do a dodge roll. It's fun for the first 15 hours, then it gets boring.

number of helpful: 3 of 7 people (43%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 7, 2015
												Note: Reason to why I have so few hours into the game will be answered also in the review. Firstly the game goes the easy ( read: lazy ) route of block-graphics ( Minecraft-inspired ). If you hate it then I think this game is not for you. I personally don't like it, but can handle it if the game is good. This seems like a nice concept: Hack-n-Slash game with community content and custom dungeons and LOOTING!!!! So what we look for in this game is how fun it is to LOOT, how fun the classes and their development is and how good the combat feels. Let's see how it fares. In those 3 aspects.Looting in this game seemed quite decent. I mean you get frequent chests, you get monster drops and "higher-value" chests and also something like a "boss"-drops. The system where you can "donate" junk and gold to shrine to "pray" for random good items for various slots is also a nice gamble and adds to all of the Gearing up aspect of an Hack-n-Slash.The combat is where the game falls flat and by a huge margin. By no means is combat any fun. The hit detection is abysmal. I feel this game has worse or more difficult combat than Dark Souls for PC and that game aims to be difficult and challenging.  Half the time you will be missing the enemy because you're not facing them, that's okay... half of the time when you are facing the enemy you still won't hit it, because your cursor is slightly off! Now even with everything angled right the hit-boxes are drunk and sway around the actual model. The classes... You have 4 classes ( 2 mages, a warrior and a semi-warrior )... All of whom mostly swing their prefered weapon, at least at the early levels. Now I want you to pick ANY 4 heroes/champions/classes from an MOBA game and imagine having a GRINDING RPG game built around them... you have 4 abilities that hardly ever improve or feel different for all of the gear grinding and loot farming. I said 4? Yes that is if you play with each and seperate one, but mostly you'll be stuck with ONE.I might have a bit biased oppinion, but that's what this god-awful combat system got me to. I have few reviews and generally prefer to write pleasant and good ones about games I like, but for me to write a negative one, the game seriously must SUCK. I understand that the game is popular amongst some of you people, but so is Minecraft... and hell if I knew why..

content:
Posted: January 2
Product received for free
												5/10. Room for improvement. For now, get it at a discount.Simple hack and slash game.I wouldn't quite compare it to Little Big Planet or even Diablo. More like Gauntlet with shareable custom dungeons.Controls are clunky and character animations are not very fluid, making the character feel unresponsive in a bad way.Moving up/down ledges is awful, i.e. the auto-jump/climb mechanic does not work well enough at all for it to be anything short of annoying 100% of the time. Feels forced.I should be able to dodge up small ledges without hitting collision. Makes dodging useless unless you are on perfectly level terrain.Walls and other geometry obscures your character too much, making it hard to see things in some levels.Camera seems far too limited for no real reason.The naming scheme for items rarely makes sense.Graphics are okay, though generic.The UI, though styled nicely modern, is not very intuitive. I did eventually get used to it.Game speed seems to be tied to framerate...? smh...

content:
Posted: September 2, 2015
												Could have been better pretty much sums up this entire game. I get more fun out of watching rich white ladies grass grow, than playing this game. Fight the Dragon is a good idea let down by poor production values, sub-par gameplay, and ugly graphics. It tries that whole voxel look, but everybody and their mom look like disformed lego people.  I get that this is an indie team, but the excution could have been better. Combat is a joke. (like the asking price of $15) it feels weak, slow and unrepesonsive, blocking is pointless, there is very little differences between classes,and there's barely a community, which something a game like this needs to stay fun and intresting. People confuse me by saying that this game is good, but hey people enjoy Postal 2 and Fable, so i guess it's somewhat understandable, in stupid way. dungeons are like potato salad alright to look at, but when you get into it you feel cheated, dissapointed, and upset, I played a player made dungeon and it was leagues above what the devs created, because it was acutally fun, and that's sad. There is nothing that great here, everything has been done better, by better games. It needed more time, and money, and it's a darn shame it didn't get it.  I hope another team picks this idea up, and does it better, cause it honestly deserves better. -2 out of 10, at least it's fun to uninstall.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 24, 2015
												UPDATE:Perhaps I was too harsh in my original review and now I feel bad about it. The game is fun in co-op and has a very neat idea. Some things can be improved upon, but overall I had a fun time playing it. It can get a little repetitive, but it is up to a community to create fun maps for it, although tools provided need a little work and I would LOVE to be able to put more stuff in adventures, right now it is kinda limited.My initial review was negative and posted after I spent almost 3 hours creating my own adventure and focusing on details only to find out I ran out off points without implementing even 1/3rd of what I wanted and never being able to publish it, because the albeit much needed anti-grind system is flawed in thinking I made an impossible challenge of puting too much traps and enemies in my adventure. Which bummed me out, cuz the whole idea of my adventure was about hard and challenging castle inspired by Dark Souls that can't be rushed. Fighting 2 bosses at a time, running under heavy ranged fire, carefully walking around traps. I've put a lot of effort in it, but ultimately couldn't published it and that really bummed me out because of the time spent designing.If you're creative type and want some good time with friends in coop in a simple game, this game might be what you want.Although creating mode is limited, there are still vast variety of adventures that can be created. I really wish you can let your fantasy run free and produce massive and detailed maps with lots of enemies and challenges, so player can sweat a little. But I realise this is not exactly a game about it. It is more simple, more relaxed and easy paced hack'n'slash game with basic controls. It's more of a kids game perhaps.Whatever the case, I am canging my recommendation, because I feel like I've been unfair in my initial review.OLD REVIEW:Right now it is really boring, super simple battle system, ui and controls for creating your own adventures are HORRIBLE, I am fighting with controls more than designing, new adventures are hard to find, it's very repetative, you can't customize your map after you've put adventures by a developer without completely erasing all of it (which is so sucky, i would've created it differently if i could). You can't create really large adventure unfortunately and very limited in your resources, and anti-grind system is flawed as hell. Hey, dude, you have too much enemies, okay, I am putting more potion chests and checkpoints -- nope, too many potion chests. WTF? Just let me create what I want, not what you feel impossible to complete. Yeah, I have a room filled with rats, but thats the challenge I want to face. Really♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥me off.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 8, 2014
												This game as it is, most definitely worth the 11 dollars I paid,  I dont even like this kind of game, I dont know why I bought it really, I am more into games like Skyrim, Fallout, Metro etc. I guess I got this game because it looked like something that could just be a fun game to play in short sessions and not have heavy decisions to make or mods to install .. What I have found is that I LIKE THIS KIND OF GAME! well this one anyway. The game is simple at face value, run around smashing stuff pick up loot, sell loot, go smash more stuff get better gear THE END.  But theres so much more, an intersting trade sytem that allows you to trade all your useless junk you found for a chance at better gear or stat points. A great dragon with a million health to try killing, and best of all, the real shining star of this game, the level editor, lots of games have level editors but I dont think any have implimented them into the game so seamlessly as this, build a level ( I can barely install windows and I managed to build one) publish it and presto there is quite litterally endless content to play that will keep leveling up from feeling like a grind. Vote levels up or down, favorite and subscribe to you favorite publishers.... great potential here. If a level is too tuff : no problem come back later and try again I LOVE the non linear approach to the "adventures". and the fact that most range from 5 to 20 minutes is nice, digestible chunks !As far as being early access there are a few quirks that could be smoothed out but nothing more than minor annoyances, seems totally playable to me.Anyway, this was a total surprise find for me and I recommend this game !

content:
Posted: September 8, 2015
												Game looks amazing at first, but then it rapidly become boring. And here is why:- it has bugs (option "Suicide" here is for a reason - you can stuck in terrain);- it's not polished, there are so many small things which prevents you from loving it;- it's not balanced, you can get uber loot from easy map and then bag full of crap after beating extreme;- there is no point in difficulty, you MUST choose the easiest, that's 50% exp, while maxed difficuly only 3x times more exp but with 10 times smaller chances to finish it, nobody care if you beat map with 0 lives, but making single failure on unknown map is too easy to spare any available life, simple math: run 3 new maps and get 3x50% exp easily -OR- run just one map, but die first time on unkown trap, die second time due to unexpected trigger spawning monster behind, die third time because of no potions left for last boss fight, which makes it total 0 exp and no loot?- UI is terrible, the guy who invent inventory is either idiot or he never himself played this game, no map, terrible idea with running between adventure/multiplayer game/switching hero and most often visited stash/altar;- lack of information, there are no clues what which stats gives in order to choose between them, tutorial message are very few (to give you an example, just few minutes ago I discovered the purpose of gold in this game.... after 13+ hours of playing....  not going to spoil, good luck in discovering if you are brave to buy this);- loud statement "community driven".. sounds like "we made map editor, we sometime add new graphics, go make us reach";- multiplayer is fantastic!, you will enjoy it as much as I did.. once.. to never try it again.All-in-all game is a fail with dated graphics, crappy mechanics and poor UI. Not recommended. You want teamplay action with puzzles and hordes of enemies? Then buy Gauntlet and not "Fight teh dragon you will never be able to beat because game is boring".

content:
Posted: September 25, 2014
Early Access Review
								This is a great start for a game!  It's a fun idea, the level creator is INCREDIBLY easy to use, and game play is pretty fun.  I like the concept of the Dragon itself!   The only thing holding this title back right now is a lack of content.  Most of the building materials are simple palette swaps of each other, or slightly different brick types.  There are seriously only like 15-20 different enemies in the whole game, and a handful of weapon/armor models.  The core of the game is there.   The devs either need to start cranking out CONTENT.  Monsters, dungeon types, objects, set pieces, etc.   That's when the game will really start to shine.  Or?  Open up the creator to let people create and share their own objects like people who mod The Sims!Also, combat.  PLEASE put more work into combat?  Combat is literally hit-for-hit, without any kind of elements, resistances, or any sort of strategy or depth at all.    I recommend this game because it shows promise.  It's definitely not done yet, and in its current state it's playable but pretty disappointing.  But there are some really awesome ideas here, and I think if they keep churning out content, this could be a phenomenal title.

												I wanted to like this and was drawn in by the positive reviews.  Sadly, it feels VERY casual and easy, bland and boring; maybe good for younger players.  It was only tolerable for about 1 hour and then I wasn't having fun.  Don't expect any class depth.  Character movement is slow and unfulfilling.  There is virtually no story. number of helpful: 3 of 8 people (38%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 6, 2014
												Im really dissappointed in this game.  it supposedly is "controller compatible". Unfortunately, that is not 100% correct.  movement and camera panning work as expected, as well as attacks and special attacks. However, the start button somehow got mapped to the right trigger as opposed to the start button on the game pad.  This is annoying since it is supposed to be the sprint button.On top of the mapping issue, there is no way to access the the right side of the "donation" menu from your controller whilst in the loot shrine (at least not that i have been able to ascertain).  The only workaround is to switch from game controller to keyboard and mouse.  I feel like im being punished for what should be a pleasureable experience. Afterall, a dungeon crawler is all about reaping the rewards found in the myriad dungeons you visit. While I fully understand the concept of minor oversight, game controls are integral to player enjoyment.  I feel like the option to map button inputs in game would have been a marvelous option. However, since that is not the case and i am  digitally flogged for attempting to sell my loot, I cannot recommend this game in its current incarnation.May the devs hear my prayer, and the game gods embolden their action

content:
Posted: December 30, 2014
												TL;DR: The level editor leaves a lot to be desired, and that was the one feature I wanted the game for.  The gameplay on its own sucks, but the loot system is decent enough.  Of course, even the loot system has its issues.The rest of the review:It's an Early Access experience, so I wasn't expecting much polish.  There's no content to the story, you just fight the dragon, hence the title.  I was OK with the lack of built-in content, because I thought I could play some user-created content that would actually be interesting.If you're buying the game for the level editor, stop.  The level editor sucks.  It isn't intuitive.  It has the beginnings of a logic editor with entity links, but you can't really make anything worth playing.  You can't have interactive dialogue with NPCs.  You can't have multi-floor buildings (well, you can if you're very clever with the bridge objects, but I think that's a glitch).  You can't make endless arena maps.  You can't make maps for Steam Workshop, the maps are built into the game instead, so your Steam profile doesn't get to display your map creations.  (Yes, you can make and share skins but that's not really interesting to me.)  Overall, it is just too limited and offers very little in terms of customization.If you're buying this game just to grind loot all day, have fun.  The loot system promotes replaying missions as efficiently as possible, only focusing on opening chests rather than fighting enemies.  You can build and play your own levels and just place all the enemies in a secluded area, away from everything else, so if you're after loot, I don't think you'll have any issues.

content:
Posted: September 25, 2014
												More Impressions @ TheVideogameBacklog.com(Early Access Impressions)With random adventures waiting around every corner, Fight the Dragon looks very promising. The aesthetics are rather basic, but the focus is on the adventure and challenges that you’ll face when you go out to level and gear up. The ultimate goal is to go and “Fight the Dragon” (what else?). Whether you’re looking to kill the dragon or just do some damage to him he’s got plenty of health do deal with.When you go out to adventure, you’ll play random levels as you pick which spot you want to go to on the over-world map (or at least that’s the best way I’ve found to describe it). You can replay levels already completed, but you won’t get a Dragon Scroll for completing them. (They allow you to fight the big jerky dragon.) You’ll get levels created by the developer (3 Sprockets) and those created by other players. You do get to vote for which maps you liked after you’ve either beaten them or been defeated by them. So far I’m in the dark of how I want to vote on some of them due to the content in them. I know that certain aspects of them are good, but if I don’t appreciate them, well… ah who am I kidding, thumbs down! After all, if you don’t like it, you don’t like it. (I like the neutral thumb more.)The best part of Fight the Dragon for me has to be, hands down, the level editor. I’m enjoying the heck out of the editor and I started by trying to recreate levels from the N64 game Goldeneye. I’ve since stopped doing that since Fight the Dragon doesn’t support multiple levels. Without having ability to create a second floor, my creation of “Not The Facility” has been halted until further progress has been made on the editor. I’m sure that’s something they may add in later. Maybe I’ll be able to make taller maps as well. As of now, you can only effectively make a tall one floor house. As for a beginning setup for crafting your own adventures, it works well enough for making dungeons and outside areas. If you’re willing to work with what you’ve got, there’s plenty of tools at your disposal to make some fun adventures for you and other players. At the very least, I would appreciate the ability to build higher even if I can’t make a second floor.There has been a few levels that remind me of what I’m not appreciating with some games lately. There’s been a fad with making games super difficult to bring back the “nostalgia of the olden times”. Some of the levels presented include way to many traps and junk that you’ll almost need prescience to know where to go. Can’t anyone remember when you just had a fun adventure and it wasn’t horribly difficult? I remember some games being difficult, but I don’t think many of those devs went out of their way to get your goat.On a flip-side, you have the ability to follow creators of your choice. It makes it a little easier to find an adventure you’ll probably enjoy more. However, I still recommend going on random adventures since that’s probably where the most fun will be, not knowing what you’re getting yourself into. You may even find yourself on my level. I’ll make more. I’m pretty happy with how the “Tunjair Desert” map turned out. Since I like to be satisfied with what I make, I’ll be taking my time and not rush anything.Score: Support This Title!With the level design loosely reminding me of Minecraft, I felt right at home creating levels. Sharing them is super easy too. There are limits to what you can actually design, but with time they may open up some options with height or creating second levels. The levels created by your fellow Steam people can range from (as much as one would expect) bland to fun to “What the …?” The fact that you can favorite designers of your choice makes it easier. It’s rather fun to play through and that stupid dragon is just begging to be stabbed. Fight the Dragon is definitely worth supporting.

content:
Posted: April 9, 2015
												The core of this game is actually very solid. It has a good loot system, good mechanics, good enough graphics, combat works well, the dragon concept and loot shrines are great ideas and even the spawn system is spot on. Unfortunately the game just doesn't go far enough to remain interesting. There are only 4 classes and each class has very few abilities and there really isn't much of any customizing to them. The loot shrine is a solid idea but it left me wishing I had something else to spend my gold on that was more interesting. The adventure design system has a really solid core, but unfortunately is just so limiting to what you can do with it that every adventure you play feels exactly the same.Overall it's a game that gets many of its core ideas right, but the lack of "more" to it just leaves you bored with the game after a short time playing it. That said, I'd love to see a Fight the Dragon 2 if they really expanded out on the character options(D3 and Torchlight 2 level), adventure tool and added in more gear gambling options.

Early Access Review
								Great game and concept, looking good so far. It's still got a few quirks here and there though, and a very VERY punishing level cap at lvl.30. This is most likely a temporary cap, unless he wants people to stop playing the game. Will update once the game gets completely playable, once there's no level cap. Until then, go watch some youtube meanwhile. 7/10, Don't buy yet.EDIT: To avoid confusion, the game isn't bad. It's just short-lived with the lvl cap. If you like spending hours reading text, playing player-made content and solving puzzles, go ahead. If you're a min-max'er you'll be coming to a halt pretty fast though, as the lvl-cap is so low. Personally, I CAN see myself playing this game a bunch if there was no cap on it. But as the Dev replied it, it will be raised in future updates. I do reccomend the game itself, but not it's current state of replayability. I reached the cap in about 4-5 hrs, for what.. 14€? Again, I will change my review once the cap is raised/removed.

number of helpful: 6 of 15 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 26, 2014
Early Access Review
								A no doubt creative project/game with an interesting concept which suffers from horribly boring gameplay.In it's core, the game is a basic (and by basic I mean REEEEEEEALLY basic) hack'n'slash style platformer. Feeling like a mix of cheap arcade platformers and a cutesy-minecraft graphics version of Diablo.Fighting comes down to just slashing away, doing the one or other dodge against bigger enemies or occasionally using a special or heavy attack. Every 'class' comes with slight differences, but I didn't really feel any different when playing as Rogue or Fire Mage.The main selling point of the game is it's 'infinite level content' by means of providing a level editor. However, after playing a few hours, I've already seen and beaten + figured out simple patterns of attack to take down all of the ~dozen enemy types the game has to offer. And here is exactly the issue: Providing players a Level Editro does NOT give you instant 'ininite content'. It just gives you infinite variations of the exact same 15 enemies placed on the same 30 tilesets. If the game would have given me the possibility to pick enemy core animations, then add in my own values and special modifiers, that would have been interesting... but like this? Boring and EXTREMELY repetitive.Not to mention trivially easy (even when I accidentally entered a high level map with a level 1 mage. Took some more kiting/time, but that's it).The concept of the dragon arena is nice. And no doubt, the dragon is a heck of a boss. But that alone does not motivate me to grind through the same enemies hours and hours to come just to beat that boss.Overall, I'm VERY disappointed with the game, even more so because it's not "This is a very early access and lots is to come" but a "It's nearly finished and very playable".Rating: 2/10Your money will get you a better hour ratio in ever other game.

number of helpful: 1 of 5 people (20%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 15, 2015
												Firstly I would like to just say that I got this game while it was on sale in a 4-pack for a total of $15-20. I believe this is a very good game and the fact is that the game is good. However, I do not recommend anyone buy this game if they are looking for games similar to what I've been looking for. To elaborate, I am looking for something medieval-like ,  something rpg-like with dungeons and new loot to find,  something challenging and fun at the same time, and most importantly it has to be  multiplayer co-op  for at least 4 people. In the months I've randomly searched when I decide to delve into the steam market I've found many games that seem almost perfect but don't have multiplayer or are too expensive for the time being. I am going to prove to you that there are better games than this that you can get that have these elements and some are even cheaper. Read on and I will explain.... This game is fun at first but the problem is the fact that it is based on you and your friends taking on random dungeons created by players. I marvel at this idea; it is brilliant. The issue is the fact that they are in fact players, that causing the obvious problem that not every dungeon is good. I am not exaggerating when I say that some dungeons I and my friends have went on are just garbage. I've spent more than 20 minutes on a dungeon with a friend when it should've taken about 5 minutes to complete. You might be thinking "Oh, that just makes it more challenging" and you'd be right, it took a long time to simply figure out that while on the inside of some castle wall (I know what you're thinking "Oh! Castle wall!!! That's so cool", this was anything but an actual castle.) we had to climb a ladder that was against the inside of the wall which happened to have a small house (not a shack, A HOUSE) which when you go inside seems to have nothing. Then you find out you have to go in a cellar there which we didn't discover existed till after killing everything on the "dungeon" (it was more of an outside area) and the only major difficulty was figuring out what to do. Mind you that this was not meant to be a puzzle, it was just bad mapmaking. You were presented with the area for this house right after you kill the things around you when you spawn. The point being is, if you expect anything as great as in the trailer video, I have not found it or even experienced anything that great. I will admit the game is fun, but what I'm trying to prove to you is that there are  BETTER ALTERNATIVES to this game if you are looking for similar things as me. Better games for you and a group of friends to try that I've played or intend to play in the future:  Trove: It's on steam, it's free, it's a 3rd person MMORPG with a bunch of fun classes like swordsman, archer, ice mage, pirate. There isn't PVP it's PVE oriented, and it has a "minecraft-esque" atmosphere. It is a voxel game which I'm normally not into but it's pretty good. Also, despite it being an MMO it does require aiming and you can dodge attacks if you jump and such, it is not lock on and just press a button to kill things like a lot of MMO's. Whenever you and your friends are near each other you all get xp despite whomever kills a creature and you all get your own specific loot drops that only you see, when you open up chests, that are based on your class. So there are no arguments over splitting up loot, you get the same amount of loot and xp with a group as solo-ing. So it's better with friends, you level up faster that way. There also are bosses at the end of dungeons. To sum it up: As my friends and I describe it, it is basically Fight The Dragon But Better. Sky Saga: Currently in alpha and free. It is not on steam and does require a key that you get when you sign up for an account on their webpage and email you a key. It is an MMORPG and very, very. similar to Minecraft in virtually every way except it's less about the building and more focused on getting quests by talking to npc's at the hub and you go on adventures. You might have to get an item you've never gotten before and bring it back to the hub, or just go take on dungeons and they do have somewhat difficult bosses in dungeons. I was co-oping a dungeon with a friend and they left for some reason and I was stuck with half health and found a boss and basically just ran out of the dungeon cause I couldn't take him. It was this big dude who had a giant lance or something and would swing it at me. To sum it up: I don't know when they will be releasing keys again as of this moment though, but definitely check this out and make an account if you're interested in playing in the future. Also be sure to check your "promotions" tab in gmail if that's what you use, it got sent there for me.Secrets of Grindea: This game I have not played or own yet. But from what I gather it is multiplayer with up to 4 players and basically a top-down RPG with monsters and boss fights. I don't know what else there is but it appears to have the elements I'm looking for in dugeon style games. It is currently $15 the same price as fight the dragon. So if you don't want to at least try the free games I mentioned and you do want to spend money still. This game is most definitely an option. To sum it up: Same price as Fight The Dragon but probably better.In Conclusion:Look up any and all of these Games and if you are truly looking for the same elements I sought after, you will not be disappointed. And if you are, you will be even more disappointed by buying Fight The Dragon. I release this review to help people like me get the best game possible for them and their friends. Good luck all and have a great day! After all you are on Steam! :)

												So, me and my FOUR year old picked it up (I needed something decently "kid-friendly" with LOCAL Coop and Controller support).TL;DR: Not 100% Coop. Very misleading. As you cannot fight the dragon with anyone else.Pros: Loot system, easy combat system, plenty of adventures, there's a dragon you can chip away at for awhileCons: The too easy combat system, TOO many crappy/unbalanced (especially some of the "easy") adventures, you can't take anyone with you to fight the dragon. Gold has no use at all other than donating (so why even bother having in the game? Not very meaningful gameplay there)I really think that if they just had some other use for the gold, and allowed coop for the dragon, and cleaned up the combat system, this would be an easy 90%+/Gold game if everything had some meaning. Otherwise, me and my four year old enjoy running around pointlessly and killing things together...Good luck on Pacman, hope that you learn from your mistakes on this one.

												Played this game for a couple hours. First off, the idea is cool. Have players make levels for you to complete, you run through them, get tons of loot, "craft" new loot, rinse and repeat.What actually happens is people put out broken levels, that wont work and then you get stuck on one for 30 mins, and if you dont complete the level, you get nothing from it. All experience, loot, etc you gained, gone. So needless to say this game got old and overly frustrating much faster then I though, and I stopped playing. So don't buy this game until it is either polished to be playable.

content:
Posted: August 30, 2015
												I bought this game for myself and some friends because I thought it would be a lovely, quirky game to play. So far I have been nothing but frustrated by the gameplay. Don't get me wrong, it isn't all bad and I do enjoy it. I just find the levels so difficult to complete that it takes the fun out of it for me. The drop items are quite fun, but unless you play a higher difficulty they are crap. The enemies are well animated and create a diverse and dynamic game, unless you play at anything over the easiest difficulty then you get swarmed and die, a lot. There is a good online element as you can play senerios that other members have created, which can result in some interesting storylines. However the game is so difficult to complete that I just cried and now have no energy to try again.Play it if you enjoy a challenge and can actually overcome it. Don't play if you have any tendency to rage quit like I do.

Early Access Review
								Interesting game. To my oppinion it's too focused on player generated content, which isnoticable when playing a map. The gameplay is bad to my oppinion. It feels like its made for a controller instead of mouse and keyboard.You can play a dungeon master however and create scenarios for other players to play and rate.Being in early access, it still requires a lot of work. You can't make a campaign yet. And claiming to give you a sort of DnD experience, it will have to improve to achieve this.They do have a good mapping rule system.A user cannot create content for more than 7000 points (at this moment).Other than that, there are rules about monsters and reaching the finish.This is further fortified by the fact that the designer has to complete his/her map at least once before publishing!However this could bite the concept in the♥♥♥♥♥if big over-arching campaigns will be made possible.Pros:- Promising concept- Campaign in the future- Maps get rated- High customizability in mapsCons:- Bad gameplay- Shallow at this moment- unintuitive editorI do suggest to eventually get it, however at this moment it is a gem in the making.

content:

Early Access Review
								This game?  Pretty terrible as of 11/9/2014Developer is snobby and has an extremely narrow view for how he wants the game to be, in spite of it being a game that relies on player-generated content.  Such douchery.  Read a bit in the community discussion and you will see he is very two-sided and arrogant.  Don't give your money on a whim, wait and see if the finished product has more potential.The combat is extremely dry, sluggish, and requires less skill and more button mashing and potion consuming.World creation is very constricting, thus turning a game that people should be able to play the way they want to into a game that might has well have been fully created by the devs.UI/inventory management needs work.  The minimal look of the UI is awesome, but the functionality of it is lacking.Art style leaves much to be desired.  I understand this is highly subjective, but it just seems uninspired.

number of helpful: 8 of 22 people (36%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 2, 2014
Early Access Review
								A potentially interesting hack and slash where you can use the included editor to create new content.Positives* I like the editablility.* Graphically the style is nice, although seems to be inconsistent on whether it is supposed to be cartoony or realistic.* Has single player and can supposedly be played offline (i haven't confirmed).* Good that levels are short so you don't get stuck being unable to save. Although, would be nice if you could save outside of levels (doesn't seem possible).* Got better once my character upgraded. Initially it was very tough going. I assume this is tuning that needs to be done as part of the early access.Negatives* Game seems very slow. My computer can run Just Cause 2 and Skyrim at high resolution very smoothly and this game is really laggy at the average settings to the point of giving me a headache.* The controls are not very tight at all. There are long delays while attacking, no indication if you are "selecting" the monster as you try to attack which leads to a lot of misses (or being low level I am suppose to miss a lot, hard to tell), and the jump mechanic could use some work.* The content is very sparse. They seem to be entirely counting on users creating most of it.* The UI is bewildering and the style doesn't match the theme of the game at all. Little things like Esc not exiting out of inventory or back up a level (you have hit tab again like TV menus), somethings can only be done in certain situations or at special locations like checking your inventory. Took me a while to figure out that the box with a number and a flashing plus was stat increases but that you have to click on the individual stas to upgrade them.* Thief doesn't start with a crossbow/bow? Seems wierd if they are going for the guantlet feel. Also, the loot drops seem to be giving me weapons for a fighter (swords, axes). I was only able to get a crossbow from the loot shrine.* Difficulty ratings are ocassionally wrong, even in the official maps. The Ice pass is definitely not "medium" having beaten several official "extreme" levels. * Bugs, i think? Somewhat expected with an early access game, but simple things like having a strength of 1+1 (+1 due to item boost) doesn't let you equip a weapon that requires a strength of 2.Overall not great based on the cost compared to other games at the same price point. That is somewhat expected with an early access game, but the developers keep talking about how playable it is, so ... I can't really recommend the game at this time. Perhaps as it matures it will get better.

content:
Posted: March 28, 2014
Early Access Review
								[After having trouble getting started, the developers got involved (in Steam community, I like it) and helped me out. Turns out the issue was the user and not the programming, sorry. Maybe that information should have been made more public? In my defense, many Linux ports are just broken, it's getting tiresome, luckily devs were on the case or I might have missed this indie gem!]Experience on Linux:+ Works.+ High developer interaction, even in Steam community. Good!+ This IS indeed the way to showcase a new game under development on Linux.The game:As expected in early access, a few key features are missing regarding controls, but it seems the devs are keen on making this a good game so we may see lots of polishing up in the near future.The game itself isn't what top end console gamers would consider good looking, but I like the artstyle. It reminds me of Egoboo (obscure title) and has that adventure feeling Neverwinter Nights used to offer. This game also has a top down platformer mechanic, much like some Zelda titles, but combines it with deeper RPG elements that we are all familiar with (XP, levels, character development, items, etc). The music is very good, it sets the tone of the game perfectly.All in all, the game delivers on every point of my expectations. If you like adventure, magic, treasure and dragons, this is your buy. Oh, it also has the number one RPG enemy: rats!Score:3/5 (still early access, with all the features in place I bet this will be a high 4 or even a 5)

number of helpful: 2 of 11 people (18%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 28, 2015
												I bought this game during the Steam Summer Sale, figuring if I didn't like it I didn't spend too much money on it.I fired it up and played a little while, figuring out the combat and loot system, as well as trying out the random and player-made adventures.  The next thing I know, 6 hours had passed and I still wanted to play more!THIS GAME IS FREAKING AWESOME!Fight the Dragon is an action hack-n-slash RPG, but one like no other you've ever played.  Sure, you get stat upgrades, tons of loot, and you fight strange mystical creatures.  FtD, however, has something I've yet to see in any other game - player made adventures!  Thousands of them, too, for hours upon endless hours of replayability!  Add to that the four unique character classes, and you're getting far more than your money's worth from this title.My personal rating?  The graphics have a cute charm to them, and while the controls can be a bit slow or clunky at times, they're very manageable.  The gameplay and replayabiolity is where this title truly shines, however.  I can see myself sinking 100's of hours into this one, and maybe even creating a few adventures of my own!  9/10  This game is PURE GOLD and worth every penny (and then some)!  Pick it up - I promise you won't regret it.

content: Posted: January 7 TL;DR @ bottomNEG: -5pts Difficult to get people to play with-2pts Grind Heroes, get loot dungeon crawler-2pts Needs music soundtrack-3pts Clunky graphics (I mean, everything looks rather fugly)-3pts It's way too easy-1pts Customization is ♥♥♥♥♥♥-3pts Loot are not special/interesting enough-100pts Where are the boss fights? (You're fighting a bunch of swarm minions all the time)A sum of -119 points.POS:+1pts Runs smooth on crap computers+1pts Easy to understand+4pts Player involvement (players can create levels for others to play)+2pts Cool bank system (you can sell items to improve other♥♥♥♥♥♥you got)+2pts Workshop+1pts It's fun for a few hours (you sometimes get riddles, sometimes get puzzles, it's a fun way to exercise your brain while you play - get's boring though)+4pts 4 different classes you can playA sum of +15 pointsSo, let's play a game, shall we? Don't worry, it's not called Dora nor Math for toddlers. The game I want to play is "Let's play an other game". Can you do that? Of course you can! TL;DR+15(GOOD) / -119(Noooot worth it) - would you buy this?:::::::::::"EDIT : DEVELOPER MADE CONTACT , GET ME THE PRESIDENT !":::::::::::Hehe, true, Seon. But I want moooore~I know it's asking a lot.. but that's what some people do.A lot. A lot. A lot. But not too much, that would make it confusing. Well, maybe even just a tiny bit would be enough for me, that is; if it is to be a very simple game. But then; we might expect it to be ingenius - which is harder to accomplish. Anyway, I really liked the idea of the game (because I like dungeon crawlers 'n♥♥♥♥♥♥, but the result up 'till now is less than attractive. This is more, but still just a review which holds little weight. I want to see more intricate adventures.. more exciting adversaries.. and definetaly more boobs. No, I jest.. boobs are for babies, everyone knows that (so what are you doing with that cow milk, sur?). (/w TL;DR a bump below)Asking players to develope your missions, our missions, is demanding of us that we create a community of creative interaction.. we need tools for this, good tools, quality tools. Like, for instance in-game forums and chats (private and chatrooms) to play more socially, create more socially. Why? Because even if this can be played solo, you don't want to play solo at all if you're a "maker of maps" (yes, titles should also be awarded!). The logic behind this is simply that you make maps for others to play them (which means you have humans and no AI's in your mind while painting)! - TL;DR :: Give players a method of finding Allies (other than seeking a dungeon party). Friendlists / Guilds / Factions / Global Chat etc. :::I hope it atleast sparks some interest in these developers, 'cuz I love myself very much and that would be awesome:::I bought 3 or 4 copies of this game, I think.. and when I show it to people they cringe, seriously.The fact that you can get different abilities (right button) with weapons is great, but there needs be a few more "chance on hit" things to force happiness. There also needs to be other joys than the mundane farming and crawling. I am saying that there should be more abilities that boasts a lot of "wow" (not the game), and more of a intelligent dungeoncrawler gameplay. There needs to be variations unknown, more patterns to crack and more playstyles to adapt to, with occasional highlights of some kind.I like the idea of having super hard maps which in the end give you something really special and valuable - achievement / title / unlockable. Why? Why ask why? Should you really why my why? Why would you even why that?Like more bosses than the dragon, pal. Pal, I already requested this.Some chain stories that you can follow would also be nice - with an end reward. F.ex:You may create chain missions through the map maker - allowing you to chain many dungeons with eachother, summarizing the points of them at the last level (or last played level with the option of taking a lesser reward early - for the impatient). In the "quest/mission selection screen" (picking levels) you may follow a chain quest by some simple means. At the end of this event, or when you choose to give in, a chest of some sort appears at your home/base/whatever - or a random evil muppet takes your candy (boss fight!) and leaves you with a princess (you don't need boobs - "where's my kale chips, muppet!?") and so you chase it.There are so many things that should be done - but what the maker makes of this game, only Psyduck and future players can tell._______________END TRANSMISSION_________________:::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::Psst;I mean, I have a lot of ideas, simple and perhaps contradictionary to what the developers are trying to accomplish here - but alas, I have no influence in these matters anyway, so I might aswell influence those who wish to buy the game. MUAHAHWHAHWHWEHAHESIdjiejkfne..M'yeeeees. I like getting mail - it often means I can EXPRESSSSSSSS my opinionsssssssss~... sssss..!

content:
Posted: April 10, 2014
Early Access Review
								I have been playing games since i was old enough to hold a controller and this is the first negative review i have ever written. This game is absolutely not worth $15, the graphics are actually worse than runescape back when it was 2d. The limited monsters are repetitive and the entire strategy of the 10 or so levels i played was pull as many monsters as possible and spam abilities, run around until stamina regenerated and then respam abilities. Items didn't even feel like they were worth picking up and as long as you can run in circles and right click you can beat almost all scenarios. The two available classes shared abilities and it didn't really feel like there was very much thought or diversity put into them. I would seriously recommend waiting or just never buying this game unless a winter sale puts it up for $1.99.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 10, 2015
												It's a nice little ARPG that focuses on user-made maps, and there are some really good ones... as well as really bad ones. You start in your central hub where you can create custom maps, pick and customize your character, change skills, sell loot to obtain various rewards, choose an adventure to embark on either solo or co-op, or have a go at fighting the dragon for special gear.For me the biggest chunk of fun i got out of the game was the editor. Think of it like Portal 2's in-game editor, it's simple, intuitive and user-friendly, if somewhat limited in certain aspects such as enemy variety.The only real problem i have with this game is it doesn't get updated often. Even just adding more content to the editor would go a long way to making the game feel larger and richer to both mapmakers and players.I recommend this to the more casual ARPG fans, and even more so to anyone who likes being a mapmaker without having to deal with overly complex editors.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 9, 2015
												This game is a lot of fun. It's one of those games that I'll play for hours on end, then stop for a few months only to pick it back up again to explore the new content. I'm enjoying the progress that the developers are making, and definitely recommend this for anyone that enjoys/enjoyed games like Gauntlet.I also highly recommend using their adventure creator. It's a lot of fun, very intuitive, and simple to use regardless of your personal experience with design. You can make extremely simple adventures or go for something more complicated - whatever suits your fancy.My only qualm is with the overall content of the game. Would love to see some additional assets for adventure creation, including monsters, props, textures, environments, skyboxes, etc. There's a lot that could be expanded upon here, and I'm sure that they'll keep adding features to make adventures more exciting to play - and to create!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 1, 2016
												So let me start off by saying when I first started playing, I actually had my doubts about the game. I kept dieing, kept getting loot I couldn't use due to class or level etc. Was driving me nuts. So I farmed a little on the beginner levels then went looking for other *easy* levels to enjoy. I like how the community is the one to create a majority of the content. Keeps it fresh and there are some extrodinary levels to play. Havent really found a *bad* one yet, just some i liked a lot more than others. Even attempted my own creation and while short, was still fun to make and play it. If you're struggling at first, give it a little time and it does get better with some gear and levels.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 13, 2015
												I apologize if you bought this game because of my first review.  I am retracting all of that. Hate to do this, I want to like this game.  Truth is, I just do not.The game works pretty well, and you can even use the editor with just a gamepad.  The combat is only okay.  There has always been something about it that just feels stiff..I guess I shouldn't complain, I got my money's worth in play time.  The funnest part is using the editor.  I made one level and published it that took quite awhile, but I didn't want to make another one because there aren't enough assets to make it very different.So that's the overall problem.  Each level feels the same because they all draw from the same small pool of assets.  For example the game only has about 20 monsters or so. Quite a while back the devs said they agreed with this and planned to add lots of stuff but they never did.  The workshop could be a solution to this, but it isn;t because you can only skin your own character, that's it.They continue to to update the game a little bit here and there, but I think they consider it mostly finished.  It's not all bad I just wish that the time I took to learn making my own edventure could be rewarded with inspiration to use it more and create many more levels.  I feel like I wasted my time with it and hope to save some others from maybe doing the same.I think the 10-13 age group could maybe like it a lot.  Hard to say, the learning curve is a bit high with the editor.  It never really caught on for my 10 year old either.

content:
Posted: June 21, 2015
												So, me and my FOUR year old picked it up (I needed something decently "kid-friendly" with LOCAL Coop and Controller support).TL;DR: Not 100% Coop. Very misleading. As you cannot fight the dragon with anyone else.Pros: Loot system, easy combat system, plenty of adventures, there's a dragon you can chip away at for awhileCons: The too easy combat system, TOO many crappy/unbalanced (especially some of the "easy") adventures, you can't take anyone with you to fight the dragon. Gold has no use at all other than donating (so why even bother having in the game? Not very meaningful gameplay there)I really think that if they just had some other use for the gold, and allowed coop for the dragon, and cleaned up the combat system, this would be an easy 90%+/Gold game if everything had some meaning. Otherwise, me and my four year old enjoy running around pointlessly and killing things together...Good luck on Pacman, hope that you learn from your mistakes on this one.

content:
Posted: December 7, 2014
												Fantastic game. Been looking for something like this for a long time. It's a hack and slash, but you can also go (ice or fire) mage or rogue (range or daggers). Maps are made by users and are of very good quality usually. There's a rating system, so it should get better over time.However, since the beginning they never fixed the main problems. Controls, poor vision, auto-pickup not working properly and most of all the Crossbow doesn't work properly and it's my favorite weapon.If you start shooting while standing still it has normal rate of fire. Usually. If you shoot while moving it takes a step, takes a shot, takes a step, takes a shot etc. This gives you less DPS. You have to stop attacking, wait a sec, stop walking too and then fire again to get it to work properly.This makes for a very awkward experience which they should have fixed by now.So for this reason I can't recommend it.(And anóther thing. The Xbox 360 controller is supported, but you can't properly aim anymore. Also you can't strafe. Playing with a controller is like playing Hammerwatch. Run away, turn around with same stick thén you can shoot the monsters that are chasing you. This isn't very hard it's just extremely awkward and slower. And no strafing? Come on!)

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 9, 2015
												Fight the Dragon is a pretty charming game.  With four classes and countless player-made levels, it offers a lot of replayability.  After getting all four classes to level 60, I have still yet to "Fight the Dragon" more than a few times. And that's one of the great things about this game, you can really play it how you want. The level editor is shockingly good and in-depth. You can make anything from a simple arena with waves of mobs or recreate your favorite D&D scenario.  My first day I stumbled upon a recreation of Diablo III Act I, the story and all. It was amazing! You could really tell the creator spent a lot of time working on it, and it was damn fun.  I have quite a few favorites that I revisit because they are so well made.  I was looking for a hack n slash style game with a light hearted feel and not so dark for a change. To be honest this fit the bill better than I could have ever imagined. Fight the Dragon was worth every cent of $15.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 17, 2015
												This game is quite a lot of fun!  It does indeed feel like a mashup of Diablo and Little Big Planet.EditorThe shining star for me is the ACK, the tools that let you create adventures. While there are plenty of tool here to make a fullout adventure and even campaign, the basics of the tools allow one to create, more or less, a dungeon.I'm impressed, certainly, by the ease-of-use of the tools.  I'm sure I'm not the only one among us, but very rarely do I read tutorials or hints and tips before using a toolset such as a level editor.  For me, I generally only retreat to tutorials if I can't figure out how to do something that I'm trying to do.  All that to say, I've not needed to look at pretty much any documentation to use these tools, they are that simple to use.  (I am a programmer by trade, though.)I sort of wish that there were some sort of an option to intentionally "complicate" the editor in order to get a little more mileage in terms of efficiency and final product quality, but I completely understand some of the design decisions that were made.GameplayAs far as gameplay goes, it's solid.  It's nothing groundbreaking, but it's nothing to complain about.  If you like ARPGs, then you'll probably like this one.  The only things I've taken note of are the predictable and exploitable AI and a probable class imbalance (There are four classes).The loot shrine is a genius idea.  for those that don't have the game, the loot shrine is basically a place where you can "sell" items and donate gold.  The more accrued value you accumulate, the better the item and rewards you get when you finally cash-in.  It gives you a mostly random output, with the player having a small amount of choice in what their reward is.Another unique aspect of this game is the dragon.  He's a really tough enemy which, I'm assuming, drops some of the best loot.  You get loot at certain milestones of health you take away from the dragon.  You can only fight the dragon, though, if you have enough tokens (Dragon Scrolls).  Each Dragon Scroll gives you a certain number of attempts to Fight the Dragon.I've not dabbled too much in fighting the dragon because I'm still fairly new and he stomps me...Other ThoughtsAs a plus, the developers and community seem quite helpful (see comments in this review) and responsive.  There were a few bugs (and a mistake on my part) that have both recently been addressed and corrected with goodwill and no malice, despite my (then) stated disappointment.  That being said, there are likely more bugs, but as of now I don't know of any that I've come across that haven't been fixed.  You'll likely not find anything gamebreaking, just things that might irk you.I sincerely hope the developers will work on a sequel and are able to take what they learned from this game to make a spectacular new game, although not in any sort of a hurry as this game still certainly has mileage left.  Sort of like LBP, which is a sited inspiration on the store page.  The first LBP was great, but had some kinks.  LBP2 seemed to work most of the little kinks and bugs out and was an excellent builder in nearly every right.TL;DR  Great adventure editor, easy to use.  Pretty good gameplay.  Possible occasional bugs.

Early Access Review
								My initial review was negative. I still think that combat is very basic that goes for both enemy and the player. Not much content, slow and daunting character progression and very limited character customisation ( luckily there is Steam Workshop ). Map editor has lots of limitations and not much variety. Camera feels too far away at times and there is no way to zoom in. So when it's all said and done why do I recommend it?-Dev's keep on adding new content.-You can create your own maps and character heads/bodies ( if you know how )-Combat even though is basic but at the same time its enjoyable. -You can play it with up to 4 players-Map editor is a blast!

Posted: February 19, 2016
												It's a fun RPG isometric game.The main objective of the game is to play and share adventures made by the players, and level up to face the dragon (the dragon is not really that important to defeat, he is a final objective but he will reward you with good loot, but you can get it also in the stages)It has simple mechanics and good game mechanics, the editor is not so intuitive so you will need to check out tutorials on how to build your own stage and specially how to make switches and traps work correctly.The bad? It seems little to no players play coop anymore (even though there is an active map creating community) and the enemy variety is very small. The graphics are also not the best, and some of the maps can have sections that are easily bugged.I would recommend specially if you have someone at home to play split screen with, or if you like creating your own quests to share with others.

												So let me start off by saying when I first started playing, I actually had my doubts about the game. I kept dieing, kept getting loot I couldn't use due to class or level etc. Was driving me nuts. So I farmed a little on the beginner levels then went looking for other *easy* levels to enjoy. I like how the community is the one to create a majority of the content. Keeps it fresh and there are some extrodinary levels to play. Havent really found a *bad* one yet, just some i liked a lot more than others. Even attempted my own creation and while short, was still fun to make and play it. If you're struggling at first, give it a little time and it does get better with some gear and levels.

												Great game with cool mechanics. The only criticism I have is that the controls are not the best. I use the mouse controls, and I understand they are not complete yet, but it still sucks when you die because of your mouse. Other than this I don't see many flaws, the combat system is fun, the dungeons are great, and the multiplayer is great. You have tons of easy to access character customization with the steam workshop, and I find the lack of DLC refreshing. I hope that the game still gets more updates, as the items seem a little bit bland as of now, but other than this the game is certainly worth 16.99!!!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 26
												There is a lot to like about this game, but it's a bit too grindy.You can make your own adventures and quests with a level editor, which is very nice. There are many player-made adventures to play through, which adds to the gameplay content. Some of these adventures are not that great and for one achievement you need to do 500 adventures... which is a bit too much because you've experienced much of what the game has offered at around the 200 mark.This brings me to the point about grinding - leveling up is very slow. Even with a few XP modifiers on your items it takes many adventures to level up once. Monsters give anywhere between a few XP to 36ish XP at around level 19 while you need about 2000 and said monsters have high health (needing up to 70+ shuriken hits each when there are many at once). Indeed, in many adventures the enemies come in too big quantities and have too much health. They have to be kited for a good while and when the two things (xp and kiting) are combined you get this tedious leveling system. Many of the weapons have so low range that only certain ranged weapon and long range melee weapons can perform well. For example, using daggers on moving enemies causes you to miss if you try to attack them from behind and axes only tend to hit one target for average damage when you could be using a hammer for AoE and higher single target DPS. Axes have the advantage of being able to use a shield, but using a shield is almost useless when enemies follow the first enemy they see, you can roll to evade and the shield is destroyed rather quickly.The class abilities are fine, I guess. Each class feels different and the game is fun to play in local or online co-op (online multiplayer is almost dead).Almost forgot - the game's soundtrack is pretty good, but the dragon boss fight is extremely disappointing. You can't properly evade its almost instant attacks and have to try again...100+ times.I would recommend the game as something to play in local co-op for a good while. 8/10
